abstract: Audiobooks are an example of a technology developed by or for people with disabilities that has helped all of us.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
headline: ‘Disability Drives Innovation’

abstract: The tech giant, which is wrapping up its arguments in the federal monopoly trial, has framed itself as a good corporate citizen that has pushed innovation and helped consumers.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two and a half weeks, Google has called a dozen witnesses to defend itself against claims by the Justice Department and a group of state attorneys general that it illegally maintained a search and advertising monopoly, in a landmark antitrust case that could reshape tech power.
headline: What Google Argued to Defend Itself in Landmark Antitrust Trial

abstract: The tech giant has dropped its plans to develop an electric vehicle, but some of the development at the heart of the effort has helped power other products and services.
lead_paragraph: Has Apple really crashed the car? The tech giant has killed its electric vehicle project as it pivots to artificial intelligence, prompting many observers to declare the venture a major failure for the company.
headline: How Apple Used its Car Project to Drive Wider Innovation

abstract: Next year we need more creative ways to bring us together. (Laundry robots would be cool, too.)
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: The Tech I Want in 2022

abstract: Unscrupulous, boundary-pushing executives seem to be an inescapable part of the most exciting technology.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Innovation Invites Hucksters

abstract: Take roof trusses.
lead_paragraph: Many of us are intrigued by wonders that scream “THE FUTURE” like flying cars. But sometimes the best inventions are more about brain power than technology magic. Let me give you a couple of examples in my quest to appreciate the ingenuity in boring things.
headline: You Can Be Both Dull and Innovative

abstract: The tech industry has grown ever more rich off big ideas that were developed more than a decade ago. New things like quantum computing and self-driving cars could take a while.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2019, Google told the world it had reached “quantum supremacy.”
headline: Why Is Silicon Valley Still Waiting for the Next Big Thing?

abstract: The strong earnings were driven by growth in the company’s grocery and e-commerce business and its strategy of keeping prices low as inflation rises.
lead_paragraph: In a difficult retail environment of rising prices and snarled supply chains, Walmart said on Tuesday that its third-quarter sales rose and earnings topped Wall Street’s expectations.
headline: Walmart beats expectations amid supply chain woes and labor costs.

abstract: New data shows how bottlenecks and the Delta variant slowed economic growth in the third quarter. Relief may be slow.
lead_paragraph: Economic growth slowed sharply over the summer, the government reported Thursday, reflecting the resurgent pandemic’s impact in keeping consumers at home and the supply-chain bottlenecks that led to empty shelves and higher prices.
headline: U.S. Recovery Hurt by Virus Surge and Supply Chain Troubles

abstract: Confession: We didn’t even have a logistics beat before the pandemic. Now we do. Here’s what we’ve learned about the global supply chain disruption.
lead_paragraph: Computer chips. Exercise equipment. Breakfast cereal. By now, you’ve probably heard: The world has run short of a great many products.
headline: How the Supply Chain Broke, and Why It Won’t Be Fixed Anytime Soon

abstract: Governments must start addressing the soaring debt used to finance pandemic aid measures, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.
lead_paragraph: The global economy’s setback from the pandemic is expected to largely stabilize by the end of next year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Tuesday, with most major economies returning to a prepandemic growth path by 2025 at the latest.
headline: Global economic growth will stabilize next year, but supply chain shock remains a risk, a report says.

abstract: Some independent stores ordered in bulk well in advance, and now are hoping they’re able to sell what they have.
lead_paragraph: Megan Searfoss has been hoarding sneakers in Connecticut.
headline: Supply Chain Problems Have Small Retailers Gambling on Hoarding

abstract: The battered industry’s next generation of leaders needs a complex set of skills, yet scaled-down store training programs aren’t meeting demand.
lead_paragraph: One of the hardest-to-find items in retail right now is a chief executive.
headline: The Retail C.E.O. Pipeline Is Running Dry

abstract: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the World Trade Organization’s director general, said bringing more countries into international production networks could make supply chains more resilient.
lead_paragraph: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the director general of the World Trade Organization, called Monday for addressing choke points in global supply chains by bringing more countries into international production networks, something she termed “reglobalization.”
headline: W.T.O. chief calls for deeper global trade to address supply chain disruptions.

abstract: The maker of luxury electric cars that hopes to challenge Tesla struggled to get parts and build vehicles in the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: Lucid Motors, a maker of widely praised electric cars that the company has struggled to mass-produce, cut its production target for the year by almost half on Wednesday after delivering just 679 vehicles in the second quarter.
headline: Lucid Motors slashes production forecast, blaming supply chain chaos.

abstract: The heads of the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of England and Bank of Japan spoke on a joint panel Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The world’s top central bankers acknowledged that inflation, which has spiked higher across many advanced economies this year, could remain elevated for some time — and that though they still expect it to fade as pandemic-related supply disruptions calm, they are carefully watching to make sure that hot price pressures do not become more permanent.
headline: The world’s top central bankers see supply chain problems prolonging inflation.

abstract: Many companies do not account for the emissions from their supply chains, which can be a significant majority of their contributions to greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 30 years, the pharmaceutical giant Bristol Myers Squibb has proclaimed it’s been setting and meeting ambitious targets around energy and greenhouse gas emissions. These days, those goals include being “carbon neutral” by 2040.
headline: Corporate Climate Pledges Often Ignore a Key Component: Supply Chains

abstract: The world’s largest maker of electric cars struggled with production problems in China.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said Wednesday that profit in the second quarter fell nearly one-third from the first quarter as deliveries slowed because of shutdowns and raw materials shortages at the carmaker’s factory in Shanghai.
headline: Tesla Profit Falls in Second Quarter as Supply Chain Problems Hurt

abstract: The global industry is cutting some ties to China, but its exposure to forced labor remains high and companies are less transparent, a new report found.
lead_paragraph: Global supply chains for solar panels have begun shifting away from a heavy reliance on China, in part because of a recent ban on products from Xinjiang, a region where the U.S. government and United Nations accuse the Chinese government of committing human rights violations.
headline: Solar Supply Chain Grows More Opaque Amid Human Rights Concerns

abstract: Federal Reserve officials are preparing to slow bond buying and are divided over when they might need to raise interest rates as inflation bites.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials were preparing to begin slowing down monetary policy support as soon as the middle of November, minutes from their September meeting showed, and policymakers debated when they might need to raise rates amid rising inflation risks.
headline: The Fed prepared to slow support for the economy and worried about supply chain disruption at its last meeting.

abstract: China’s capital city is not as central to global production networks as Shanghai, but the costs for global companies will still mount if lockdowns spread.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of further lockdowns in China prompted a fresh wave of economic anxiety on Monday as investors and companies whose supply chains run through China contemplated the impact of 70 new virus cases that the Beijing government said it had detected over the weekend.
headline: The prospect of lockdowns in Beijing fuels more concerns about supply chain disruptions.

abstract: A surge in Omicron variant infections has prompted Chinese authorities to lock down residents, close factories and stop truck traffic, snarling already frayed supply chains.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Trucks are being delayed by the testing of drivers. Container rates are rising as ships wait for many hours at ports. Products are piling up in warehouses.
headline: China’s Covid Lockdowns Set to Further Disrupt Global Supply Chains

abstract: With the contract of union workers at West Coast ports nearing expiration, the prospect of a labor impasse threatens another shock to the global economy.
lead_paragraph: In a world contending with no end of economic troubles, a fresh source of concern now looms: the prospect of a confrontation between union dockworkers and their employers at some of the most critical ports on earth.
headline: New Supply Chain Risk: 22,000 Dockworkers Who May Soon Strike

abstract: The Consumer Price Index increased at the fastest pace in 40 years, a new report showed.
lead_paragraph: Inflation climbed to its highest level in 40 years at the end of 2021, a troubling development for President Biden and economic policymakers as rapid price gains erode consumer confidence and cast a shadow of uncertainty over the economy’s future.
headline: Consumer prices popped again in December, casting a shadow over the economy.

abstract: Lengthy and expanding walkouts by the United Automobile Workers union against Ford, General Motors and Stellantis could strain a fragile supply chain.
lead_paragraph: More than a week into its targeted strike at the three established U.S. car companies, the United Automobile Workers union has poked holes in a supply chain that has still not fully recovered from the pandemic.
headline: Drivers and Dealers Could Soon Feel Impact of U.A.W. Strikes

abstract: President Biden has made a push to unclog ports, address trucker shortages and take other steps to alleviate the pressure created by consumers looking to buy couches, cars and electronics instead of eating out or going to theme parks.
lead_paragraph: President Biden told executives from some of the nation’s largest retailers on Monday that his administration was committed to partnering with them to untangle supply chains and ensure that American consumers can find everything they want this holiday season, as a surge in shopping tests an already strained global delivery system.
headline: The Biden administration, under fire for supply chain woes, says stores will be fully stocked for the holidays.

abstract: The supply-chain problems rocking companies may get worse heading into the holidays, as delays continue to snarl global trade and shipping prices jump even higher.
lead_paragraph: Catrike has 500 of its three-wheeled bikes sitting in its workshop in Orlando, Fla., nearly ready to be sent to expectant dealers. The recumbent trikes have been waiting for months for rear derailleurs, a small but crucial part that is built in Taiwan.
headline: What an Adult Tricycle Says About the World’s Bottleneck Problems

abstract: The trade deficit in September climbed to $80.9 billion, a record. Imports rose slightly, while exports fell.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. trade deficit hit a record $80.9 billion in September, reflecting a surge in imported goods that continued to outpace American exports, data released by the Commerce Department on Thursday showed.
headline: The U.S. trade deficit rose as a surge of imports bogged down the supply chain.

abstract: The automaker said shortages of parts are continuing to hurt its ability to make and sell vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said on Monday that the costs of parts would be $1 billion higher in the third quarter of the year than it had expected because of inflation and shortages of some components.
headline: Ford Says It Will Spend $1 Billion More in Third Quarter Because of Supply Chain Problems

abstract: Expectant parents have keenly felt the inconvenience of global shipping delays caused by the pandemic. With a baby due, “it’s a different ballgame.”
lead_paragraph: Almost as soon as Eryn Yates made it through her first trimester of pregnancy last spring, she started shopping for her dream nursery.
headline: What to Expect When You’re Expecting: Supply Chain Issues

abstract: Pandemic-related product shortages — from computer chips to construction materials — were supposed to be resolved by now. Instead, the world has gained a lesson in the ripple effects of disruption.
lead_paragraph: Like most people in the developed world, Kirsten Gjesdal had long taken for granted her ability to order whatever she needed and then watch the goods arrive, without any thought about the factories, container ships and trucks involved in delivery.
headline: The World Is Still Short of Everything. Get Used to It.

abstract: China’s Covid lockdowns and restrictions are holding up truck drivers who carry crucial components among factories and take products to ports, posing a new disruption to the global supply chain.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s mounting Covid-19 restrictions are creating further disruptions to global supply chains for consumer electronics, car parts and other goods.
headline: Lockdowns in China Block Truck Shipments and Close Factories

abstract: Supply chain problems hamper Boeing and Airbus as they try to fulfill a spate of orders from carriers seeking to expand and rejuvenate their fleets.
lead_paragraph: Airlines are desperate to get more planes to meet insatiable and growing travel demand, but the two major plane manufacturers, Boeing and Airbus, are struggling to keep up.
headline: Airlines Need New Planes, but the Supply Chain Has Other Ideas

abstract: The war in Ukraine has highlighted the risks of doing business with authoritarian countries — not just Russia, but also China.
lead_paragraph: The auto assembly lines going quiet in Germany, Britain and Austria are more than just another example of how fragile supply chains have become. The shutdowns may foreshadow a fundamental reordering of the global economy that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will accelerate.
headline: Car Industry Woes Show How Global Conflicts Will Reshape Trade

abstract: Companies are testing whether the United States can regain some of the manufacturing output it ceded in recent decades to China and other countries.
lead_paragraph: When visitors arrive at the office of America Knits in tiny Swainsboro, Ga., the first thing they see on the wall is a black-and-white photo that a company co-founder, Steve Hawkins, discovered in a local antiques store.
headline: Supply Chain Woes Prompt a New Push to Revive U.S. Factories

abstract: A proposal, and the rapid retreat that followed, both elicited waggish mockery and highlighted a serious economic problem.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Australian government has been trying all kinds of things to address a pandemic labor shortage: Letting international students work more hours. Reimbursing visa costs to lure backpackers. Easing isolation requirements for essential workers.
headline: Australia’s (Brief) Idea to Ease Supply Chains: Juvenile Forklift Drivers

abstract: Businesses around the country are facing what could be the latest disruption to how they get their goods to their customers in a timely and affordable fashion.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Keeler and her husband, Stuart de Haaff, own an olive oil company in the hills of central California. The couple spend their days harvesting olives, bottling the oil, labeling the glass bottles and shipping them out, relying primarily on UPS to get their product to kitchens throughout the United States.
headline: Looming UPS Strike Spurs Some Companies to Rethink Supply Chains

abstract: Human rights activists and others urged the Biden administration to cast a wide net to stop imports of products made with forced labor in Xinjiang.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Human rights activists, labor leaders and others urged the Biden administration on Friday to put its weight behind a coming ban on products made with forced labor in the Xinjiang region of China, saying slavery and coercion taint company supply chains that run through the region and China more broadly.
headline: Supply Chains Widely Tainted by Forced Labor in China, Panel Is Told

abstract: Russia is incubating a cottage industry of new digital surveillance tools to suppress domestic opposition to the war in Ukraine. The tech may also be sold overseas.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Ukraine unfolded last year, Russia’s best digital spies turned to new tools to fight an enemy on another front: those inside its own borders who opposed the war.
headline: Cracking Down on Dissent, Russia Seeds a Surveillance Supply Chain

abstract: The yawning disparity between the performance of the electric car company and established automakers last year reflects the technological change roiling the industry.
lead_paragraph: For much of last year, established automakers like General Motors and Ford Motor operated in a different reality from Tesla, the electric car company.
headline: Why Tesla Soared as Other Automakers Struggled to Make Cars

abstract: The company said it expected to produce only 25,000 electric vehicles this year, adding a new cloud to its outlook only months after a hot I.P.O.
lead_paragraph: Rivian, which has had a rocky ride in the stock market after a blockbuster initial public offering, cast a further shadow over its outlook on Thursday, reporting that supply chain problems could severely constrain its production of electric vehicles.
headline: Rivian Pares Delivery Targets for 2022, Citing Supply Problems

abstract: Companies start reporting their third-quarter earnings this week, and profits are expected to have risen substantially. But worries of future growth are growing.
lead_paragraph: The Delta variant of the coronavirus has hurt hiring and made policymakers’ lives more difficult. But investors are taking it in stride, because it appears to have had little effect on corporate profits.
headline: As earnings season begins, inflation and supply chain issues cloud the outlook.

abstract: The companies behind e-commerce are embracing automation as the means of transcending the limitations of humans.
lead_paragraph: The people running companies that deliver all manner of products gathered in Philadelphia last week to sift through the lessons of the mayhem besieging the global supply chain. At the center of many proposed solutions: robots and other forms of automation.
headline: The Supply Chain Broke. Robots Are Supposed to Help Fix It.

abstract: Shortages in construction materials are likely to delay the efforts to rebuild in the aftermath of the devastating storm.
lead_paragraph: In normal times, the devastation of a massive hurricane like Ida tends to be followed by an aggressive rebuilding effort, as carpenters, roofers and other skilled workers descend on affected communities to repair the damage.
headline: Hurricane Ida could make the supply chain disaster even worse.

abstract: Just as the global economy was on track to emerge from the coronavirus pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and global sanctions against Moscow are rippling through logistics and supply chains, creating bottlenecks in the transport of goods and commodities and threatening fresh economic pain for countries and businesses near the conflict zone.
lead_paragraph: Just as the global economy was on track to emerge from the coronavirus pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and global sanctions against Moscow are rippling through logistics and supply chains, creating bottlenecks in the transport of goods and commodities and threatening fresh economic pain for countries and businesses near the conflict zone.
headline: The global supply chain’s pandemic recovery is another casualty of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

abstract: A maker of medical devices can’t keep up with customer demand as the shortage of computer chips puts it in competition with bigger companies with more clout.
lead_paragraph: For much of this year, Joseph Norwood’s next breath was locked in a zero-sum competition with people eager to upgrade their iPhones.
headline: How the Supply Chain Upheaval Became a Life-or-Death Threat

abstract: As shipping companies concentrate on the most lucrative routes from China to California, almond growers are struggling to transport their wares.
lead_paragraph: During a normal spring, the sight of orchards bursting with clusters of almonds is a boon throughout California’s Central Valley. Here is money growing on trees.
headline: How America’s Farmers Got Cut Out of the Supply Chain

abstract: Under the legislation, known as a due diligence law, businesses would need to establish regulations to detect, prevent and mitigate breaches of human rights.
lead_paragraph: Large companies operating in the European Union could be held responsible for environmental violations or human rights abuses committed by businesses in their supply chains under a law proposed on Wednesday by the European Commission, the bloc’s administrative arm.
headline: Companies in the E.U. could be held liable for violations along their supply chain.

abstract: Sixty-one vessels were anchored offshore on Thursday waiting to unload cargo at the Port of Los Angeles and the Port of Long Beach, down from 73 on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Container ships were lined up this week off the coast of Southern California, waiting to deliver cargo at the Port of Los Angeles and the Port of Long Beach. The backup offered another sign of the supply chain woes bedeviling businesses across the globe.
headline: A record number of cargo ships off the California coast shows a crack in the supply chain.

abstract: Seven months after Washington unveiled tough curbs, Chinese companies are doubling down on homegrown supply chains and drawing billions in cash from Beijing and investors.
lead_paragraph: Last October, construction plans for a hulking semiconductor factory owned by a major state-backed company in central China fell into disarray. The Biden administration had escalated the trade war over technology, severing China’s access to the Western tools and skilled workers it needed to build the most advanced semiconductors.
headline: ‘De-Americanize’: How China Is Remaking Its Chip Business

abstract: Focusing on electric vehicles, Volkswagen aims for growth in North America, though it could face tough competition.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen is shifting its focus toward North America, as the fallout from Russia’s attack on Ukraine caused more supply chain headaches for the company in Europe, executives said.
headline: Volkswagen eyes U.S. market as war in Ukraine disrupts European production.

abstract: The maker of electric pickup trucks, vans and sport utility vehicles affirmed its production forecast for the year.
lead_paragraph: Rivian, a fledgling electric-vehicle manufacturer, said Thursday that it lost $1.7 billion in the second quarter.
headline: Rivian Reports $1.7 Billion Quarterly Loss as Supply Chain Problems Persist

abstract: The automobile pioneer believed short-term interests must not squeeze out investment in a business’ resilience, a lesson many companies have learned the hard way since 2020.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Henry Ford, the godfather of mass production, was tormented by the possibility of running out of parts and raw materials. Suspicious of financiers — a spirit that animated his fervent antisemitism — he was especially distrustful of his suppliers. He was consumed with stockpiling enough materials to ensure that his assembly lines could continue operating without debilitating shortages.
headline: Lessons From Henry Ford About Today’s Supply Chain Mess

abstract: If freight trains stop rolling, the result could be chaos for business, shortages for consumers, and fresh momentum for rising prices.
lead_paragraph: Just as the global supply chain flashes signs of returning to normal, a new crisis now threatens to disrupt the transport of a vast range of goods, from agricultural crops to lumber to coal.
headline: How a Rail Strike Could Wreak Havoc on the American Supply Chain

abstract: The surge in coronavirus cases is idling workers at ports and trucking companies, while strong consumer demand continues to drive up the cost of shipping and energy.
lead_paragraph: Persistent challenges in getting goods from factories to customers continue to drive up the price of cars, computer chips, furniture and other products, pushing up consumer prices in December at the fastest rate since 1982.
headline: Supply chain snags continued to drive up prices in December.

abstract: As forests succumb to ever-fiercer wildfires, the federal government and some adventurous private companies are trying to resuscitate an industry.
lead_paragraph: When it came to wildfires, 2021 was an increasingly common kind of year in Montana: Flames consumed 747,000 acres, an area nearly the size of Long Island.
headline: How to Revive a Burned Forest? Rebuild the Tree Supply Chain

abstract: U.S. and European companies looking to diversify from China are expanding around Southeast Asia, a sign of how geopolitics is reshaping tech manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: Construction cranes still surround the brand-spanking new plant in Kulim’s industrial park in Malaysia. But inside, legions of workers hired by the Austrian tech giant AT&S are already gearing up to produce at full capacity by year’s end.
headline: Malaysia Rises as Crucial Link in Chip Supply Chain

abstract: The company, the world’s largest maker of wind turbines, said pandemic delays in China and the rising cost of steel were hindering earnings.
lead_paragraph: Wind energy projects are being proposed around the world to help meet climate goals, but the largest maker of turbines is finding that supply chain issues and pandemic lockdowns are hampering wind farm construction and hurting financial results.
headline: Vestas, a Danish wind giant, warns of supply chain turbulence.

abstract: The chaos at ports, warehouses and retailers will probably persist through the year, and perhaps even longer.
lead_paragraph: With the havoc at ports showing no signs of abating and prices for a vast array of goods still rising, the world is absorbing a troubling realization: Time alone will not solve the Great Supply Chain Disruption.
headline: A Normal Supply Chain? It’s ‘Unlikely’ in 2022.

abstract: The carmaker had a profit of $5.5 billion as sales of its electric vehicles kept soaring, especially in China and Europe.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said Wednesday that its profit leapt more than sixfold last year to $5.5 billion, the highest total in its 19-year history, as sales soared further, especially in Europe and China.
headline: Tesla reports record yearly profit but warns that supply problems persist.

abstract: Policymakers are discussing how to be less reliant on adversarial countries at the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Thursday that global supply chains had proved to be unstable amid the pandemic and Russia’s war in Ukraine and called for a reshaping of trade relationships oriented around “trusted partners,” even if it meant higher costs for businesses and consumers.
headline: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen calls for a reshaping of global supply chains that are ‘not secure.’

abstract: Government officials and energy developers misjudged the difficulty of building huge clean energy projects in the United States, which has built very few of them.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, interest in offshore wind energy was so strong that developers proposed spending tens of billions of dollars to plunk hundreds of turbines the size of skyscrapers in the Atlantic Ocean from Maine to Virginia.
headline: What Ails Offshore Wind: Supply Chains, Ships and Interest Rates

abstract: They’re shifting to domestic sourcing and production, like some big manufacturers, but with at least one advantage the giants don’t have.
lead_paragraph: What’s more stressful than a nightmare you can’t wake up from? For Ken Rosenblood, it’s watching ships, tiny dots on a radar, stuck at sea, unable to deliver the lifeblood of your company. That’s how he remembers the early days of the pandemic.
headline: Weary of Snarls, Small Businesses Build Their Own Supply Chains

abstract: Athleisure company, one of the few retailers to thrive during the pandemic, relies heavily on production from Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: Even as Lululemon reported soaring sales on Wednesday and forecast a robust holiday season, the athleisure company sounded a note of caution because of pandemic-related factory shutdowns in Vietnam, echoing concerns about the global supply chain voiced by many apparel retailers in recent weeks.
headline: Lululemon says sales are soaring but supply chain issues remain a concern.

abstract: Administration officials are pushing for a settlement to head off a walkout by tens of thousands of workers on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Biden administration officials are racing to prevent a strike by tens of thousands of freight railroad workers that could further disrupt an already strained supply chain and cause billions of dollars in economic damage.
headline: Strike Threat on Freight Railroads Is New Supply Chain Worry

abstract: As Houthi rebels intensify strikes on vessels headed for the Suez Canal, global shipping prices are soaring, raising fears of product shortages and delays.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Loomis had hoped that the chaos besieging the global supply chain was subsiding. The floating traffic jams off ports. The multiplying costs of moving freight. The resulting shortages of goods. All of this had seemed like an unpleasant memory confined to the Covid-19 pandemic.
headline: ‘It’s All Happening Again.’ The Supply Chain Is Under Strain.

abstract: The administration’s economic advisers see climate change and other factors complicating global trade patterns for years to come.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic and its ripple effects have snarled supply chains around the world, contributing to shipping backlogs, product shortages and the fastest inflation in decades.
headline: Supply Chain Hurdles Will Outlast Pandemic, White House Says

abstract: Facing delays, shortages and higher prices for raw materials, small manufacturers are finding new sources. Not all are able to pass along the costs.
lead_paragraph: Peak season has arrived for DPS Skis, a manufacturer and distributor of mountain sports gear in Salt Lake City. But this year, the winter challenges began far from the slopes.
headline: Made in the U.S.A., but With a Supply-Chain Reboot

abstract: Automakers and steel companies reported disruptions as a job action entered a seventh day.
lead_paragraph: A truck-driver strike in South Korea stretched into a seventh day on Monday, forcing the country’s manufacturers to scale back production and slowing traffic at its ports.
headline: Striking truck drivers in South Korea snarl supply chains.

abstract: The highly intricate and interconnected global supply chain is in upheaval, and in one way or another, much of the crisis can be traced to the outbreak of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: The highly intricate and interconnected global supply chain is in upheaval, and in one way or another, much of the crisis can be traced to the outbreak of Covid-19.
headline: How the Supply Chain Crisis Unfolded

abstract: The Federal Reserve chair spent the early pandemic bemoaning the loss of a strong job market. It roared back — and now its fate is in his hands.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, spent the early pandemic lamenting something America had lost: a job market so historically strong that it was boosting marginalized groups, extending opportunities to people and communities that had long lived without them.
headline: Jerome Powell’s Prized Labor Market Is Back. Can He Keep It?

abstract: Openings were little changed, but hiring and quitting both declined.
lead_paragraph: Job turnover decreased in June, the Labor Department reported on Tuesday, suggesting that the American labor market continues to slow down from its meteoric ascent after the pandemic lockdowns.
headline: Job Turnover Eased in June as the Labor Market Cooled

abstract: The jobless rate in February, 2.1 percent, was close to the lowest ever. Employers are adjusting to the power of workers.
lead_paragraph: Harry’s Wonder Bar is a trusted old dive in Nebraska’s capital, frequented by office clerks, construction workers and graduate students alike: the sort of wood-paneled place with a pool table in the back where phones generally stay in pockets, second fiddle to casual conversation, and beer mugs come frosted regardless of the season.
headline: ‘I’m in Hot Demand, Baby’: Nebraska Thrives (and Copes) With Low Unemployment

abstract: The March data increased confidence among economists and investors that robust hiring and rising wages can continue to coexist while inflation eases.
lead_paragraph: Another month, another burst of better-than-expected job gains.
headline: U.S. Employers Added 303,000 Jobs in 39th Straight Month of Growth

abstract: The U.S. job market continues to ease off its red-hot pace, a government report shows, but there are still more openings than unemployed workers.
lead_paragraph: Demand for workers in the United States eased in February, a sign that the red-hot labor market continues to cool off somewhat.
headline: Job Openings Fell in February as Labor Market’s Slow Cool-Down Continued

abstract: Amid the pandemic, people thought the labor market had permanently changed in important ways. It was a bad bet.
lead_paragraph: Remember the “she-cession”? What about the early-retirement wave, or America’s army of quiet quitters?
headline: The Pandemic’s Labor Market Myths

abstract: March data showed a cooling labor market, but layoffs remain low. The overall trend is likely to be welcomed by Federal Reserve policymakers.
lead_paragraph: The red-hot labor market cooled somewhat in March, government data showed on Wednesday.
headline: Job Openings and Hiring Are at a 3-Year Ebb

abstract: Employers appear to be responding to rising interest rates and a slowing economy by reducing open positions.
lead_paragraph: The number of job openings fell for the third consecutive month in June, a sign that the red-hot U.S. labor market may be starting to cool off.
headline: Job openings fell in June, suggesting that the labor market is cooling.

abstract: Government data for October shows the labor market is still strong, though cooling slightly.
lead_paragraph: Employers continued to pull back in October on the number of jobs they were looking to fill, the latest sign that the labor market is strong but gradually cooling.
headline: Job Openings Ease, but Layoffs Are Little Changed

abstract: Vacancies fell to 8.8 million, the lowest level since March 2021.
lead_paragraph: The number of job openings continued to drop in July, the Labor Department reported Tuesday, another sign that the U.S. labor market is losing its momentum.
headline: Job Openings Dropped in July as Labor Market Cooled

abstract: U.S. employers added 353,000 jobs in January, far exceeding forecasts, and revised figures showed last year was even stronger than previously reported.
lead_paragraph: The United States produced an unexpectedly sizable batch of jobs last month, a boon for American workers that shows the labor market retains remarkable strength after three years of expansion.
headline: Job Market Starts 2024 With a Bang

abstract: Japan’s improved labor force participation for women is a reminder not to assume that job market limits are clear and finite.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s economy has rocketed into the headlines this year as inflation returns for the first time in decades, workers win wage gains and the Bank of Japan raises interest rates for the first time in 17 years.
headline: Japan’s Labor Market Has a Lesson for the Fed: Women Can Surprise You

abstract: Federal Reserve officials are tasked with fostering “full employment.” At least for now, some see the labor market as uncomfortably tight.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are tasked with fostering “full employment,” and while it has been difficult to guess what that means as the economy recovers from huge job losses at the start of the pandemic, March hiring data seemed likely to reaffirm to policymakers that the labor market is running hot.
headline: The Fed eyes a hot labor market as unemployment nears prepandemic levels.

abstract: The economy added 311,000 jobs in February despite higher interest rates. But hourly earnings rose more slowly as the pool of available workers grew.
lead_paragraph: The labor market continued its energetic expansion in February, extending a hotter-than-expected streak that has created abundant job opportunities while frustrating the Federal Reserve in its drive to contain stubborn inflation.
headline: U.S. Employers Keep Hiring, but Signs of Easing Are Seen

abstract: The ratio of open jobs to available unemployed workers fell to the lowest level since October 2021.
lead_paragraph: Job openings in March fell to 9.6 million, the Labor Department reported on Tuesday, the lowest level in two years and a further indication that the slowdown in the labor market is becoming more entrenched. It was the third straight month that job openings have declined, a notable development after last year, when job openings bounced around month to month.
headline: Job Openings Slipped in March as Labor Market Continued Cooling

abstract: The decline in new virus cases and the relaxation of restrictions in some places seem to have relieved pressure on employers.
lead_paragraph: The American economy has shaken off the worst of the recent layoff surge, government figures indicated Thursday, but the job market remains daunting.
headline: Unemployment Claims Fall, but Labor Market Remains Turbulent

abstract: With Covid prompting more employers to consider remote arrangements, employment has soared among adults with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: The strong late-pandemic labor market is giving a lift to a group often left on the margins of the economy: workers with disabilities.
headline: For Disabled Workers, a Tight Labor Market Opens New Doors

abstract: The number of U.S. positions available was 11.3 million in May, the second straight monthly decline.
lead_paragraph: Employers became slightly less desperate for workers in May as job openings declined for the second straight month from a record high in March.
headline: Job openings eased, in a sign of the cooling labor market.

abstract: Lael Brainard, a Federal Reserve governor, argued that the job market was not tight, and John C. Williams, the president of the New York Fed, said it had “a long way to go.”
lead_paragraph: Top Federal Reserve officials emphasized on Monday that the labor market was far from completely healed, underlining that the central bank will need to see considerably more progress before it will feel ready to raise interest rates.
headline: Top Fed officials say the labor market needs more time to heal.

abstract: Men ages 35 to 44 are staging a lackluster rebound from pandemic job loss, despite a strong economy.
lead_paragraph: For the past five months Paul Rizzo, 38, has been delivering food and groceries through the DoorDash app. But he spent the first half of 2022 earning no paycheck at all — reflecting a surprising trend among middle-aged men.
headline: Why Are Middle-Aged Men Missing From the Labor Market?

abstract: After scrambling to fill out work forces in recent years, many companies are reporting more modest goals for temporary employment.
lead_paragraph: As the most important selling season for retailers approaches, job applicants may feel a chill.
headline: Retailers’ Seasonal Hiring Plans Signal a Cooling Labor Market

abstract: Hiring was largely unchanged, and the number of workers quitting their jobs increased. The data will be watched closely by Federal Reserve policymakers.
lead_paragraph: Job openings fell in May while the number of workers quitting their jobs increased, the Labor Department reported Thursday.
headline: Job Openings Dipped in May, a Sign of Continued Cooling

abstract: Government data from November showed job openings remained high, with rates of quitting and layoffs holding steady.
lead_paragraph: The labor market remained a key source of strength for households and the overall economy ahead of the holiday season, even as hiring struggles remained a headache for employers, the latest government data indicates.
headline: Labor Market Strength Persisted Heading Into the Holidays

abstract: Even with the Fed raising interest rates, employers are still eager to hire.
lead_paragraph: Demand for workers remained strong in July, a sign that the U.S. labor market remains vibrant even as the Federal Reserve tries to cool the economy by raising interest rates.
headline: Job Openings Picked Up in July, Showing the Labor Market Remains Hot

abstract: Time magazine, The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times — owned by Marc Benioff, Jeff Bezos and Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong — are still losing money.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old saying about the news business: If you want to make a small fortune, start with a large one.
headline: Billionaires Wanted to Save the News Industry. They’re Losing a Fortune.

abstract: The European Central Bank expects to bring down inflation, with a big caveat: Companies need to let profits fall as they pay for higher wages.
lead_paragraph: The eurozone’s inflation challenge is moving into a new phase, where the driver of domestic price pressures is shifting from company profits to wages, officials at the European Central Bank said this week as they tried to lay the groundwork for a long period of high interest rates.
headline: Europe’s Inflation Issue Moves Into a New Phase: From Profits to Wages

abstract: The automaker reaffirmed its forecast for earnings for the full year.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is now being squeezed by inflation as well as a global computer chip shortage.
headline: G.M. Profit Falls 40 Percent as Costs Rise and Chips Are Lacking

abstract: The company also announced a new U.S. battery factory and said it would stop production of its top-selling electric car, the Chevrolet Bolt.
lead_paragraph: General Motors on Tuesday reported an 18.5 percent drop in profits in the first quarter, mainly because of the cost of job cuts and slowing new-vehicle sales in China. The company also announced that it would build a fourth battery factory in the United States while retiring the electric car that accounts for most of its sales in that category.
headline: G.M.’s Profits Fell 18.5% in the First Quarter

abstract: From motels to spa treatments, the industry has often used Indigenous imagery to gain a sense of authenticity. Amid an ongoing national conversation around race, will that change?
lead_paragraph: John Gunderman believed his vision for a campground with 70 tepees, 12 hogans and 43 Conestoga wagons in the Arizona desert off Route 66 would “invoke nostalgia that transcends to every generation.”
headline: Is Travel Next in the Fight Over Who Profits From Native American Culture?

abstract: The company has 222 million customers, with 67 million in the U.S., and expects to add 8.5 million subscribers in the December quarter.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a tale of two Netflixes over the last few weeks, as a long-anticipated Dave Chappelle special drew sharp condemnations from staffers and critics alike and as the South Korean sleeper hit “Squid Game” became a global sensation, making it the streamer’s most-watched series to date. (Both detail a grim view of the world.)
headline: Netflix beats estimates and expects even better results thanks to hits like ‘Squid Game.’

abstract: Interest in new iPhones and services such as music and cloud storage powered the quarter, but other businesses, such as Mac sales, slowed significantly.
lead_paragraph: At a time when the tech industry’s biggest companies are rebounding from a post-pandemic dip, Apple is suffering through its most prolonged sales slump in more than a decade.
headline: Apple’s Sales Drop Slightly While Profit Is Up 11 Percent

abstract: Oil prices have climbed in recent months and are now roughly where they were before the pandemic’s full force was felt.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two biggest oil companies in the United States, on Friday reported their first quarterly profits after several quarters of losses, signaling that the energy industry is rebounding from the coronavirus pandemic.
headline: Exxon Mobil and Chevron report first quarterly profits after several losses.

abstract: Three large U.S. airlines have reported strong quarterly sales and profits in recent days because of strong demand, high fares and relatively low fuel prices.
lead_paragraph: Summer travel is off to a roaring start, with little sign of a slowdown on the horizon. And airline executives say they are doing all they can to keep up, including contending with bad weather and congestion in the skies and on the ground.
headline: Airlines Are Thriving as People Keep Traveling

abstract: The company continues to lean on customers’ appetite for apps and services, as demand for its devices weakens.
lead_paragraph: Difficulties have been piling up for Apple. In recent months, it has been sued by the Justice Department, fined by European regulators and challenged by the resurgence of a Chinese smartphone competitor.
headline: Apple Reports Decline in Sales and Profit Amid iPhone Struggles in China

abstract: The bank reported lower quarterly profits, but it expects to earn significantly more money later this year from rising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America joined its peers in reporting lower profits for the first three months of the year but is keeping its optimistic economic outlook even as other lending giants have turned more cautious.
headline: Bank of America is confident in the economy even as its profits declined.

abstract: The electric car company made $1 billion in the second quarter as its revenue roughly doubled from the same period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Tesla on Monday reported a big increase in profit for the three months ending in June because it sold more than twice as many cars in the period as it did a year earlier.
headline: Tesla reports a big jump in profit.

abstract: It was the first time the social media giant’s revenue had fallen since it went public a decade ago, as it confronts increased regulatory scrutiny and a turbulent economy.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Facebook’s sales grew without fail and kept on growing, defying the laws of gravity even as the company was battered by scandals over privacy and misinformation.
headline: Meta reports first revenue decline and a 36 percent profit drop.

abstract: It was a steep fall from last year’s record profit, but still enough for the company to introduce additional dividend payments and increase capital investment.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest energy company, on Monday reported a nearly 40 percent drop in profit for the second quarter, compared with a year ago, when high oil prices produced record earnings.
headline: Saudi Aramco Reports $30 Billion in Profit for Latest Quarter

abstract: Coinbase has shown that a large, profitable and legal business can be built to service the growing groups of people who want to use the digital currencies.
lead_paragraph: Coinbase, the cryptocurrency exchange, said on Tuesday that its quarterly revenue soared by more than 1,000 percent and profits skyrocketed nearly 4,900 percent from a year earlier, in its second earnings report as a publicly traded company.
headline: Coinbase rides cryptomania to a $1.6 billion quarterly profit.

abstract: The results easily topped analysts’ forecasts.
lead_paragraph: Google’s parent company, Alphabet, shrugged off any concerns about a downturn in online advertising with another quarter of blockbuster earnings, lifted by continued strong demand for ads on YouTube and steady growth at its cloud computing business.
headline: Google’s profit and revenue soared in the third quarter.

abstract: The loans have ensnared hundreds of thousands of students, who aren’t protected by the same government safeguards carried by federal loans.
lead_paragraph: Kashia Campbell earned top grades from her patient care technician program at Florida Career College. So she was shocked to find that, upon graduation, she was blocked from the exam to get certified in the field.
headline: Left in the Lurch by Private Loans From For-Profit Colleges

abstract: Lenders foresee economic “headwinds,” but household spending is mostly holding up, buffering profits from turmoil in financial markets.
lead_paragraph: Big banks are bracing for an economic slowdown but haven’t yet seen any major signs of trouble, as consumer spending remained strong despite the dent that market turbulence left in their latest quarterly profits.
headline: Big Banks’ Profits Drop, but Consumers Cushion the Blow

abstract: “Digital adoption curves aren’t slowing down,” Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, said in a statement. “They’re accelerating.”
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Tuesday reported that its quarterly sales grew at one of its strongest rates in years, as the company was poised to cross $2 trillion in market value.
headline: Microsoft reports strongest quarterly growth in years, as profit also rises.

abstract: The automaker reported a sharp drop in profits in the third quarter after slashing car prices by around 25 percent in an attempt to compete.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s profit slumped in the third quarter, disappointing Wall Street expectations, after the carmaker cut prices to maintain its dominance of the market for electric vehicles.
headline: Tesla’s Profits Plunge 44% After Big Price Cuts

abstract: The Wall Street giant’s earnings fell by nearly 70 percent in its latest quarter, a steeper decline than its peers, as it set aside more money to cover sour loans.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs, long the most envied firm on Wall Street, has stumbled into the New Year.
headline: Goldman Sachs Lags Rivals as Profit Plunges

abstract: Alphabet initially was seen as vulnerable to the pandemic, but has come out of it stronger.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, just made in three months what it took until recently an entire year to earn. That is a level of growth that companies of its size rarely if ever achieve, but the pandemic has erased all the limits for tech firms.
headline: Google’s profits soar as revenue rises 62 percent.

abstract: Google’s parent company reported earnings that were below analysts’ expectations, bringing in $13.9 billion in profit on $69.1 billion in sales.
lead_paragraph: Even Alphabet, the parent company of Google and one of the internet’s most entrenched businesses, was not immune to the punishing blows of the global economy and a sharp slowdown in the online advertising that is essential to the company’s profits.
headline: Alphabet’s Profit Drops 27 Percent From a Year Earlier

abstract: The carrier’s $68 million fourth-quarter profit was its first in two years without government aid.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines on Thursday reported a $68 million profit for the final three months of last year as it struggled to shake off setbacks caused by the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, which has delayed the travel recovery and is expected to drag the airline to a loss in the first three months of this year.
headline: Southwest Airlines posts a quarterly profit as it tries to shake off Omicron woes.

abstract: The earnings by Google’s parent company were below analysts’ expectations of $17.5 billion in net profit on $69.9 billion in revenue.
lead_paragraph: Google’s search engine business is demonstrating resilience in the face of a slowing economy and rising inflation, but its other businesses have not been able to escape a downturn in online advertising.
headline: Alphabet’s profit dropped 14 percent in the second quarter.

abstract: The retailer said total revenue rose to $153 billion in its most recent quarter, up 0.5 percent from a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Walmart navigated rising inflation and fickle consumer confidence in its fourth quarter, as sales rose and profit increased, beating analysts’ expectations.
headline: Walmart profits grow as consumers continue to spend.

abstract: The company’s $8.5 billion profit beat expectations, rounding out a series of bumper reports by the biggest Western oil companies.
lead_paragraph: BP, one of the world’s largest oil companies, easily beat expectations for second-quarter profit on Tuesday as high prices and constrained supply drove up earnings for energy companies.
headline: BP is the latest oil giant to report a huge quarterly profit.

abstract: The electric carmaker had to close an important factory in Shanghai because of China’s efforts to stamp out a coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said on Wednesday that it made a $3.3 billion profit in the first three months of the year, up from $438 million a year earlier and the biggest quarterly profit since the company’s creation. But Tesla also said it expected its factories to run below capacity for the rest of 2022.
headline: Tesla’s profits jumped in the first quarter, but challenges loom.

abstract: The automaker also reported a big jump in revenue, to $13.8 billion from $8.8 billion a year ago, as sales of the Model Y continue to rise.
lead_paragraph: Tesla made $1.6 billion in the three months ending in September, the second quarter in a row that its profit has exceeded the billion-dollar mark.
headline: Tesla’s quarterly profit nearly quintuples to $1.6 billion as car sales surge.

abstract: Investors were closely watching business spending with the company’s cloud computing division, which grew 12 percent in the most recent quarter.
lead_paragraph: Amazon reported solid quarterly sales on Thursday, showing that corporations and consumers are spending as inflation has eased.
headline: Amazon Revenue Jumps as Consumer and Business Spending Improves

abstract: Nestlé and Procter & Gamble reported resilient earnings as they brought in more money from selling fewer goods.
lead_paragraph: Nestlé and Procter & Gamble, two of the world’s largest consumer-facing companies, continued to raise prices last quarter, generating higher sales even as shoppers, squeezed by inflation, cut back on the amount of cereal, yogurt, detergent and other goods they bought, the companies reported on Wednesday. Executives also said that the prices would remain high in the coming quarters.
headline: Consumer Giants Keep Raising Prices as Profits Come Under Pressure

abstract: The world’s largest maker of electric cars struggled with production problems in China.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said Wednesday that profit in the second quarter fell nearly one-third from the first quarter as deliveries slowed because of shutdowns and raw materials shortages at the carmaker’s factory in Shanghai.
headline: Tesla Profit Falls in Second Quarter as Supply Chain Problems Hurt

abstract: The Wall Street investment bank earned $3 billion in the second quarter, more than double the tally from a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs on Monday reported a hefty jump in its quarterly profits as the company continued its climb out of a self-inflicted morass.
headline: Goldman Sachs’s Revamp Takes Shape With Another Profit Haul

abstract: A new rule will put the companies that own some for-profit schools on the hook if their campuses defraud students or close their doors.
lead_paragraph: The Education Department says it will hold companies that own certain private colleges financially responsible for taxpayers’ losses if their schools defraud students or abruptly shut down.
headline: The Education Department says owners will have to pay if their colleges collapse.

abstract: One of the nation’s largest banks reported across-the-board strength in its latest quarter, with sales and earnings that surpassed analysts’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America, one of the nation’s largest lenders, on Tuesday reported across-the-board strength in its latest quarter, with sales and profit that surpassed analysts’ expectations, like the three megabanks that reported their earnings last week.
headline: Bank of America Reports Profit Jump on Higher Interest Rates

abstract: Companies’ rising profit margins could be contributing to persistent inflation, a European Central Bank policymaker says.
lead_paragraph: After months of fretting about whether workers’ rising pay would keep inflation uncomfortably high, central bankers in Europe have another concern: large company profits.
headline: Are Big Profits Keeping Prices High? Some Central Bankers Are Concerned.

abstract: Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley, Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase have all reported quarterly profits that beat analysts’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: Experts are warning that U.S. economic growth may be easing. But as far as the country’s biggest banks are concerned, the recovery is going just fine.
headline: The big banks are bullish about the recovery.

abstract: Larry Fink’s latest annual letter to corporate America clarifies, and defends, his approach to social and environmental issues at the world’s largest money manager.
lead_paragraph: Laurence D. Fink, the founder and chief executive of the investment giant BlackRock, has become one of the most influential voices in business over the past decade in pushing corporate leaders to think beyond profits, to their social purpose.
headline: It’s Not ‘Woke’ for Businesses to Think Beyond Profit, BlackRock Chief Says

abstract: The first-quarter results are likely to fuel worries that competitors will continue grabbing a bigger slice of a market dealing with slowing electric car sales.
lead_paragraph: Tesla reported on Tuesday that it made significantly less money in the first three months of the year because of its tepid car sales, reinforcing concern among investors that the company led by Elon Musk is losing ground in the market for electric vehicles.
headline: Tesla’s Profit Fell 55%, Adding to Concerns About Its Strategy

abstract: Britain is raising a tax on gas and oil producers, and adding a levy on companies that supply electricity — a similar approach to that of other governments chasing revenue.
lead_paragraph: Major oil and gas companies have raked in multibillion-dollar profits at unheard-of levels. Households around the world are reeling from soaring energy prices, while governments are struggling with outsize spending and slowing economic growth.
headline: Will Taxing the Windfall Profits of Oil Giants Fix Countries’ Economies?

abstract: Revenue at Fox Corporation dropped as fewer viewers tuned into the company’s cable channels and the Fox broadcast network. The company also announced the acquisition of OutKick Media.
lead_paragraph: Fox News, the cable news giant controlled by Rupert Murdoch, kept its parent company flush in the first three months of the year, notching a slight gain in profit and sales despite a drop in viewers.
headline: Fox News keeps profits flowing at Murdoch’s Fox Corporation.

abstract: The investment bank reported a profit half as large as its rival Morgan Stanley, to say nothing of larger lenders.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs on Wednesday reported quarterly profit that fell short of even dampened expectations, another reminder of the troubles facing one of Wall Street’s premier names.
headline: Steep Profit Fall at Goldman Sachs Highlights Wall St. Giant’s Woes

abstract: Wall Street investors were hoping the social media giant would regain its footing after more than a year of problems, including slumping ad sales.
lead_paragraph: Long before it was called Meta, Facebook was a Wall Street darling because of its breakneck growth and big profits. But the company had lost its luster with investors over the past 18 months thanks to a slump in ad sales and what some saw as self-inflicted wounds.
headline: Meta Profit Is Up 16% to $7.8 Billion in Recent Quarter

abstract: Resource-rich countries like Ghana are often cut out of lucrative parts of the business like manufacturing. The “fairchain movement” wants to change that.
lead_paragraph: The first leg of the 35-mile journey from Ghana’s capital city, Accra, to the Fairafric chocolate factory in Amanase on the N6 highway is a quick ride. But after about 30 minutes, the smoothly paved road devolves into a dirt expanse without lanes. Lumbering trucks, packed commuter minivans, cars and motorcycles crawl along craggy, rutted stretches bordered by concrete dividers, muddy patches and heaps of rock.
headline: How West Africa Can Reap More Profit From the Global Chocolate Market

abstract: Exxon Mobil and Chevron reported another round of strong profits. But they face political fire over gasoline prices, even as they fear a new downturn.
lead_paragraph: The good times are back for the oil companies, but with the global economy on edge, there is more caution than celebration among executives.
headline: Oil Giants, With Billions in Profits, Face Criticism and an Uncertain Outlook

abstract: Revenue was up 18% in the latest quarter, the tech giant said, as investors look for signs that it’s beginning to profit from artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Microsoft topped Apple as the most valuable public company. Last week, it surpassed $3 trillion in market valuation. Next week, Satya Nadella will hit his 10th anniversary as the company’s chief executive.
headline: Microsoft Reports 33% Rise in Profit

abstract: To see where technology is headed and why, follow the money.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Profits Steer Our Digital Future

abstract: A Facebook whistle-blower explains her motivations.
lead_paragraph: The hits keep coming for Facebook. Last night, in an interview on “60 Minutes,” a former Facebook product manager described how she had leaked internal documents to The Wall Street Journal. The newspaper had published a series of eye-opening articles dubbed “The Facebook Files,” detailing what the social media giant knew about the harms its platform was causing.
headline: ‘Profit Over Safety’

abstract: The tax on the “extraordinary” profits of oil and gas companies is expected to raise 5 billion pounds and help fund £15 billion in payments to households.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government said it would use a windfall profits tax on oil and gas companies to help raise funds for direct payments to households, totaling about 15 billion pounds (about $19 billion), to ease the country’s cost-of-living crisis.
headline: Britain Will Tax Oil and Gas Profits as Cost-of-Living Crisis Swells

abstract: Europe’s largest energy company said it would use some of the earnings to buy back more shares and increase its dividend.
lead_paragraph: Booming prices for oil and natural gas propelled Shell’s profit in the fourth quarter of 2021, lifting its adjusted earnings to $6.39 billion, up from $393 million a year earlier, the company reported Thursday.
headline: Shell’s profit jumps, riding higher prices for oil and natural gas.

abstract: The oil and gas giant said it would resume its stock buyback program by repurchasing $10 billion in shares over the next two years.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil, the largest American oil company, reported its most robust earnings in seven years on Tuesday as it rode a wave of climbing oil and natural gas prices.
headline: Exxon Mobil reports a $8.9 billion fourth-quarter profit as oil prices soar.

abstract: The automaker, which owns Jeep, Ram and Peugeot, said its profit had more than doubled, thanks to higher prices and cost-cutting measures that outweighed the semiconductor shortage.
lead_paragraph: The automaker Stellantis said its profit more than doubled in 2021 to 13.3 billion euros, a result of cost savings and higher car prices that more than offset disruptions to production and sales caused by the global shortage of computer chips.
headline: Stellantis reports a big profit even as a chip shortage hurt production.

abstract: In the third quarter, the companies continued their rebound from the collapse in demand at the start of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two dominant American oil companies, reported a third consecutive quarterly profit on Friday as petroleum and natural gas prices continued to climb higher.
headline: Exxon Mobil and Chevron continue to report higher profits, helped by rising oil prices.

abstract: The conglomerate saw major gains in its insurance operations and in investment income. But revenues at its railroad and utility businesses declined from 2022.
lead_paragraph: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run for decades by Warren E. Buffett, recorded its highest-ever annual profit last year. But its chief executive found reason to blame government regulation for hurting the results of some of its biggest businesses.
headline: Berkshire Hathaway Reports Profit of $97 Billion Last Year, a Record

abstract: The social network has constructed a vast infrastructure to keep toxic material off its platform. At the center of it is Accenture, the blue-chip consulting firm.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Julie Sweet, the newly appointed chief executive of the global consulting firm Accenture, held a meeting with top managers. She had a question: Should Accenture get out of some of the work it was doing for a leading client, Facebook?
headline: The Silent Partner Cleaning Up Facebook for $500 Million a Year

abstract: Overcoming the worst of a global chip shortage, the automaker sold more cars and trucks, and prices were higher.
lead_paragraph: Automakers are seeing improvements in the supply of computer chips, but shortages continue to disrupt production.
headline: Ford’s quarterly profit is up nearly 20% from a year earlier.

abstract: The results in the latest quarter are a sign of the company’s financial strength as it faces a public relations crisis.
lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Monday that revenue rose 35 percent to $29 billion in the three months ending in September compared with the same period last year, while profit rose 17 percent to $9.2 billion, a sign of the social network’s financial strength as it faces a public relations crisis over troubling disclosures made by a former employee.
headline: Facebook’s profit jumps 17 percent.

abstract: Credit Suisse has been unsettled by a number of setbacks, including billion-dollar entanglements with bankrupt lenders and hedge funds, large legal settlements and management upheaval.
lead_paragraph: In what is becoming a habit for Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking giant warned investors on Wednesday that it was likely to lose money in its latest quarter. This would be Credit Suisse’s third loss-making quarter in a row, each of which was preceded by a warning that the results would be worse than the bank had initially expected, as it reels from a series of crises and upheavals.
headline: Another quarter, another profit warning from Credit Suisse.

abstract: The bank earned $9.7 billion in the third quarter, down from last year. It also added to reserves against loan losses and took a hit on some investments.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase earned $9.7 billion in the third quarter, a 17 percent drop from what it made during the same period a year ago, reflecting a wobble in global financial markets and the effect of higher interest rates, but no real trouble for the largest bank in the United States.
headline: JPMorgan’s Profit Shrinks, but Chief Says U.S. Customers Are ‘Healthy’

abstract: The results were below analysts’ expectations for a net profit of $17.33 billion on revenue of $68.05 billion.
lead_paragraph: Google’s pandemic boom may finally be slowing.
headline: Alphabet’s profit drops 8% as Google’s pandemic boom shows signs of slowing.

abstract: More people splurged on computers as they worked and learned from home, driving sales of Macs to grow by 70 percent.
lead_paragraph: Apple said on Wednesday that its profits more than doubled to $23.6 billion in the most recent quarter as people embraced its latest iPhones and bought more of its other products, striking results for what is already the world’s most valuable company.
headline: Apple doubles its profits on soaring iPhone sales.

abstract: The pandemic has been a windfall for Apple and its peers, as people buy even more gadgets to work, study and socialize.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s profits nearly doubled in the latest quarter, showing that the world’s richest and most valuable public company is exhibiting little sign of slowing down.
headline: Apple’s profits nearly doubled in the latest quarter.

abstract: The company raised prices 10 percent across its consumer brands for a second straight quarter and said its profit margin had widened.
lead_paragraph: Another round of price increases on household products like Gillette razors, Dawn dish soap and Swiffer dusters bolstered Procter & Gamble’s bottom line last quarter, the company said on Friday, a sign that stubborn inflation may linger as companies defend their profit margins.
headline: Double-Digit Price Increases Bolster Profits at Procter & Gamble

abstract: But at nearly $32 billion, the oil giant’s quarterly earnings still far exceeded those of Western rivals, and it announced an increase in dividend payments.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco on Tuesday reported $31.9 billion in net income for the first quarter, a drop of about 19 percent compared with the same period a year ago, mainly because of lower oil prices.
headline: Falling Oil Prices Cause Saudi Aramco’s Profit to Slip 19 Percent

abstract: The energy company said quarterly profit had more than doubled from a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: BP, the London-based energy giant, reported its highest profit in a decade on Tuesday. The company said its underlying replacement cost profits were $6.2 billion for the first quarter of 2022, more than double the $2.6 billion of a year earlier.
headline: BP writes off $25.5 billion on its Russia pullout, but oil and gas profits soar.

abstract: The automaker earned more than $6 billion last year — money that it will plow into the development of electric and autonomous vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Despite a pandemic that shuttered auto factories for nearly two months and sent car sales tumbling, General Motors made more than $6 billion last year, one of its highest profit totals ever.
headline: G.M.’s Profits From Trucks and S.U.V.s Fuel Its Electric Quest

abstract: How easily companies give up swollen profits could determine how easily the Federal Reserve can cool inflation. Dealerships offer clues.
lead_paragraph: In a recent speech pointedly titled “Bringing Inflation Down,” Lael Brainard, the Federal Reserve’s vice chair, zoomed in on the automobile market as a real-world example of a major uncertainty looming over the outlook for price increases: What will happen next with corporate profits.
headline: What’s Next for Profits? Cars Shed Light on a Key Inflation Question.

abstract: The bank reported a 25 percent decline in profit in the third quarter, versus last year, in part because of “very challenging markets.”
lead_paragraph: The negative effects of market turbulence outweighed the positives from consumer spending at Citigroup, the third largest bank in the United States, in the third quarter. The bank’s quarterly profit, announced on Friday, was down from the previous year but better than analysts expected, a sign that Main Street, if not Wall Street, remained resilient.
headline: Citigroup’s Profit Falls as Consumer Strength Is Offset by Market Weakness

abstract: General Motors sold more cars in the third quarter after struggling with a shortage of computer chips earlier in the year.
lead_paragraph: General Motors on Tuesday reported an increase in earnings for the third quarter as a surge in vehicle production offset the impact of rising interest rates and higher prices for parts and materials.
headline: G.M. Reports Jump in Profit on Strong Sales

abstract: The tech giant’s quarterly results included strong growth in cloud computing, fueled by its services in generative artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft gave more signs on Thursday that its hefty investments in artificial intelligence were beginning to bear fruit, as it reported a 17 percent jump in revenue and a 20 percent increase in profit for the first three months of the year.
headline: Microsoft Reports Rising Revenues as A.I. Investments Bear Fruit

abstract: The national oil company of Saudi Arabia said quarterly income reached nearly $40 billion, reflecting volatile energy markets.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the national oil company of Saudi Arabia, reported on Sunday net income of $39.5 billion for the first quarter of 2022, a jump of about 80 percent from the same period a year earlier, largely reflecting higher oil prices.
headline: Saudi Aramco cashes in on rising oil prices as profit jumps 80 percent.

abstract: But shortages of computer chips remain a problem, and could curtail production of as many as 90,000 vehicles at BMW alone this year.
lead_paragraph: The global car market is rebounding strongly despite shortages of key components like semiconductors. That was the message Tuesday from German carmaker BMW and Stellantis, which owns Jeep, Peugeot and Fiat, as both reported large increases in profit.
headline: BMW and Stellantis report big jumps in profit as car sales snap back.

abstract: The conglomerate’s results reflected the turmoil in financial markets and the broader slowdown in U.S. economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, on Saturday reported a sharp decrease in earnings in the third quarter, reflecting the turbulent financial markets as well as a slowdown in the U.S. economic recovery with a spike in Covid-19 cases. Profits fell by two-thirds to $10 billion, down from $30 billion in the same three months of 2020, when the economy was still in the process of reopening from pandemic shutdowns.
headline: Berkshire Hathaway’s Profit Fell in the Third Quarter

abstract: The company had its first $5 billion quarter for its gaming business, as people looked for entertainment at home and Microsoft launched the long awaited new generation of its Xbox console.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft continued to benefit from the pandemic’s shift to remote computing and gaming, with revenue and profits reaching new heights in the latest quarter, the company said on Tuesday.
headline: Microsoft profits jump 33 percent as pandemic continues shift to cloud computing.

abstract: Ahead of the critical holiday shopping season, the nation’s largest retailer reported stronger-than-expected earnings and signaled confidence with a $20 billion share buyback.
lead_paragraph: Walmart on Tuesday reported a rise in sales in its latest quarter, signaling that consumers continued to spend despite high inflation and that the retail behemoth had moved past the missteps that plagued it earlier this year. It also increased its full-year forecast for revenue and profit, and projected confidence by announcing a $20 billion share buyback.
headline: Walmart Defies Gloom Over Inflation With Sales and Profit Upgrade

abstract: The company’s profit soared 31 percent, to $816 million, in the last three months of 2021.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks will increase prices this year, the coffee giant said on Tuesday, blaming supply chain disruptions and a sharp rise in labor costs.
headline: Starbucks will raise prices again, citing higher costs for supplies and workers.

abstract: Alphabet posted revenue of $55.31 billion, up 34 percent from a year earlier, and net profit more than doubled to $17.93 billion in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: Google’s parent company, Alphabet, said on Tuesday that revenue in its most recent quarter increased sharply from the same period a year ago, boosted by strong demand for online advertising on its search results and YouTube videos and by continued growth at its cloud computing arm.
headline: Alphabet’s profit more than doubled last quarter as Google’s advertising business rebounded.

abstract: Some companies and restaurants have continued to raise prices on consumers even after their own inflation-related costs have been covered.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, a bag of potato chips at the grocery store cost an average of $5.05. These days, that bag costs $6.05. A dozen eggs that could have been picked up for $1.83 now average $2.90. A two-liter bottle of soda that cost $1.78 will now set you back $2.17.
headline: Food Prices Soar, and So Do Companies’ Profits

abstract: Corporate leaders expect rosy company earnings, starting this week.
lead_paragraph: After closing the books on the second quarter, executives are the most positive they have ever been about the profits their companies are generating, according to data from FactSet. And that might be a good sign that bottom-line growth will continue even after the expected rebound from the pandemic economic plunge.
headline: Wall Street Sees Blowout Profits Ahead

abstract: General Motors has struggled with electric vehicles and in foreign markets but it is selling lots of combustion engine cars and trucks in North America.
lead_paragraph: General Motors on Tuesday reported a big jump in profits for the first three months of the year, based on the strength of its gasoline vehicle business, and raised its outlook for the rest of the year.
headline: G.M. Reports Big Jump in Profit on Gasoline Car Sales

abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo comfortably beat expectations for earnings in the first quarter, when the failures of smaller banks sent jitters through the sector.
lead_paragraph: The country’s largest banks escaped the crisis that just weeks ago brought down two midsize U.S. lenders, unnerving regulators and depositors. If anything, the tumult helped those giants rake in bumper profits.
headline: Biggest U.S. Banks Report Bumper Profits Amid Industry Turmoil

abstract: Authors Equity is tiny but has big industry names behind it. Its founders hope their profit-sharing approach and experience will entice authors.
