lead_paragraph: A new book publisher with an unusual business model, a small footprint and an outsize pedigree that includes some of the biggest names in publishing launched on Tuesday.
headline: A New Publisher Promises Authors ‘the Lion’s Share of the Profit’

abstract: What a difference a year makes.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, SoftBank disclosed its biggest-ever operating loss, and its voluble founder, Masa Son, spoke ruefully of the “valley of coronavirus” that ensnared its investments. Now, thanks to huge I.P.O.s, the tech giant is setting a different — and much happier — record.
headline: SoftBank Broke Profit Records. Can It Keep Up the Pace?

abstract: The company unveiled details of an ad-supported Disney+ as demand at its theme parks rebounded.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bucking a streaming slowdown that has recently bedeviled Hollywood, Disney+ added 14.4 million subscribers in the most recent quarter, about 45 percent more than Wall Street had expected and lifting Disney’s portfolio of streaming services to 221 million subscribers worldwide, edging ahead of Netflix for the first time.
headline: Disney Profit Jumps 50%, and Streaming Subscriptions Surpass Netflix

abstract: The parent company of the streaming services Disney+, ESPN+ and Hulu announced the change in updated service agreements this week.
lead_paragraph: Fans of “The Bear” won’t be able to use a friend’s Hulu account to watch Season 3.
headline: To Boost Profits, Disney Cracks Down on Password Sharing

abstract: The network is on a pace to drop below $1 billion in profit for the first time in years, according to people familiar with its operations, amid steep declines in TV viewership.
lead_paragraph: One of the first moves the newly formed Warner Bros. Discovery made when it took over CNN was shutting down CNN+, the nascent streaming service that was touted as the network’s bridge to the future.
headline: Profits Slump at CNN as Ratings Plummet

abstract: The iPhone maker said sales of its flagship product were down 8 percent as it dealt with a factory shutdown and worries about rising inflation.
lead_paragraph: When a Covid-19 outbreak in China forced a lockdown of Apple’s largest iPhone factory in November, the world’s most valuable company warned investors that it would lose sales. The question was: How much?
headline: Apple Revenue and Profit Down as iPhone Sales Slow

abstract: The earnings were driven by success in the company’s Microsoft Cloud business, which includes Office 365 subscriptions and Azure.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft produced its most profitable quarter. Again.
headline: Microsoft profit soars 48%, to $20.5 billion.

abstract: The company said its vaccine generated $3.5 billion in revenue in the first three months of this year.
lead_paragraph: Last year, racing to develop a vaccine in record time, Pfizer made a big decision: Unlike several rival manufacturers, which vowed to forgo profits on their shots during the Covid-19 pandemic, Pfizer planned to profit on its vaccine.
headline: Pfizer Reaps Hundreds of Millions in Profits From Covid Vaccine

abstract: Like other carriers, American benefited from a travel rebound, but higher costs took a toll on its bottom line.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines reported $13.4 billion in revenue in the three months that ended in June, the best quarter in the company’s history.
headline: American Airlines has its best quarter of revenue ever, but profit is down from 2019.

abstract: The company, a chain of new-vehicle franchises, has been able to cut back on discounts as the chip shortage limits the inventory of cars.
lead_paragraph: The global shortage of computer chips has wreaked havoc on auto production, but it is also helping to pump up the bottom lines of auto retailers.
headline: AutoNation’s profit jumps as prices for cars soar.

abstract: Revenue for the first three months of the year jumped 11 percent from a year earlier, the automaker reported.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Tuesday that its profits dipped in the first three months of the year. But the company said it expected to grow rapidly as it started selling a wider range of electric cars and trucks.
headline: G.M.’s profits fell 3% in the first quarter as chip shortages limited production.

abstract: The bank will combine trading and investment banking into one unit; asset management, wealth management and consumer businesses into another; and its digital offerings in a third.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is taking another step away from its past as a clubby Wall Street partnership, adopting a new three-pronged structure that combines investment banking and trading into one unit; merges asset and wealth management into another; and elevates its digital offerings into a third unit, the bank announced on Tuesday.
headline: Goldman Sachs Restructures Its Divisions, Elevating Tech Offerings as Profit Falls

abstract: The automaker has placed a bet on electric vehicles, but it has struggled to produce and sell the vehicles in large numbers.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Tuesday that its profit in the final three months of 2023 was depressed by the cost of a 40-day strike at some of its U.S. plants and an accounting charge related to electric vehicles.
headline: G.M. Profits Hurt by Electric Car Business and Strike

abstract: Banks continued to release funds they had set aside last year in preparation for hefty loan losses that never materialized.
lead_paragraph: Americans are ramping up spending. That’s good for big banks’ bottom lines.
headline: Bank of America reports a big profit, and Citi and Wells Fargo beat expectations.

abstract: SoftBank reported more than $11 billion in profit for the three months that ended in December, driven by surging values in its  investments in companies like Uber and  DoorDash.
lead_paragraph: For many technology companies, the past 12 months have been a roller coaster, starting with a pandemic-driven market-wide sell-off in March and ending with one of the largest stock market run-ups in history. But for Japan’s SoftBank, which manages the world’s largest tech investment fund, it has been an especially wild ride.
headline: SoftBank posts a quarterly profit of $11 billion to end a turbulent 12 months.

abstract: The Wall Street giant joined the country’s other big banks in beating analysts’ earnings expectations.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs joined the rest of the country’s biggest banks in reporting profits that beat expectations, fueled by hot markets for stocks and corporate deals.
headline: Goldman Sachs’s profit surges on record merger activity.

abstract: Traditional sports owners who invested in competitive video gaming say the money isn’t flowing in as quickly as they had expected.
lead_paragraph: It had been more than three hours of tense, back-and-forth combat — projected across the massive Jumbotron at San Francisco’s Chase Center — when the sellout crowd, thumping together inflatable thundersticks and yelling with excitement, sensed victory was at hand.
headline: The Excitement Around E-Sports Is Growing. But Where Are the Profits?

abstract: The record haul, pushed by high energy prices and a hunger for liquefied natural gas, came as a new chief signaled a more “balanced approach” to renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: Shell, Europe’s largest energy company, reported a bumper profit for 2022 on Thursday: $42.3 billion, more than double its 2021 total and probably a record for any British company.
headline: Shell’s Profit Soared to $42 Billion Last Year

abstract: The iPhone maker’s recent quarter benefited from strong sales in its App Store and other services businesses.
lead_paragraph: The smartphone industry is in a tailspin, with unit sales falling for two straight years, but Apple has escaped the worst of the downturn because wealthy customers continue buying pricey iPhones.
headline: Apple Revenue Drops 1%, but Profit Rises to $19.88 Billion

abstract: Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, has been criticized for selling few electric vehicles, but its decision to focus on hybrids is paying off financially.
lead_paragraph: In today’s high-tech, high-stakes auto industry, fortunes can change quickly, and there’s no better example of that right now than Toyota Motor.
headline: Toyota’s Hybrid-First Strategy Is Delivering Big Profits

abstract: The carmaker said the six-week strike by the United Automobile Workers union had cost it $800 million so far and could cost $200 million for every week it continued.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Tuesday that it made $3.1 billion in profit from July through September, a year-over-year decline of more than 7 percent that was partly due to the six-week strike by the United Automobile Workers union.
headline: G.M. Profit Down 7% in Strike-Affected Quarter
Catch up: Apple and Facebook profits doubled last quarter.

abstract: The company’s revenue and profit beat Wall Street expectations, easing concerns that supply chain problems and the coronavirus were a drag on sales.
lead_paragraph: Apple weathered the supply chain snarls at the end of 2021 that tripped up the global electronics market and other industries, announcing on Thursday an 11 percent increase in revenue and a 20 percent jump in profit in its most recent quarter while offering optimism that the worst of the problems were behind it.
headline: Apple’s profit jumps to $34.6 billion in holiday quarter despite supply issues.

abstract: The retailer’s second-quarter profit fell 90 percent from the year before, far below what Wall Street analysts were expecting.
lead_paragraph: Target posted quarterly earnings on Wednesday that were much weaker than Wall Street expected, as the retailer got rid of excess inventory that built up as shoppers shifted their buying habits. Company executives presented the actions as tough but necessary to position the retailer for a stronger performance in the rest of the year.
headline: Target’s Profit Sinks as It Offloads Inventory Shoppers Don’t Want

abstract: Its sales of $49.4 billion in the first quarter were up 18 percent from a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Despite inflation and uncertainty over the war in Ukraine, Microsoft on Tuesday reported financial results that showed little threat to the fundamentals of its business.
headline: Microsoft reports rising revenue and profits, despite war and inflation.

abstract: The company’s quarterly revenue rose 25% as its costs fell after layoffs last year.
lead_paragraph: Meta on Thursday reported a 25 percent increase in quarterly revenue while profit more than tripled, a rise fueled by its ads business after a shaky 18 months of layoffs and a rocky digital advertising market.
headline: Meta Reports Profits More Than Tripled and Issues Its First Dividend

abstract: The giant oil producer said it earned nearly $50 billion last quarter, the latest energy company to record outsize profits after the surge in crude prices since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the giant oil producer, said on Sunday that its second-quarter profit jumped 90 percent over the same period a year ago, reaching $48.2 billion. It is the latest energy producer to report bumper earnings on the back of a surge in the price of oil.
headline: Saudi Aramco’s Profit Jumps 90 Percent on High Oil Prices

abstract: The oil industry enjoyed record profits in 2022 after Russia invaded Ukraine, but the prices of oil and natural gas have fallen sharply in recent months.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest American oil companies, reported relatively modest earnings growth on Friday as they were forced to manage their businesses in the face of sagging prices for oil and natural gas.
headline: Exxon and Chevron Report More Modest Profits as Oil and Gas Prices Ease

abstract: For the year, Goldman notched its largest profit ever, $21.6 billion, helped by deal-making by its investment bankers.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported a record $21.6 billion profit last year, but its fourth-quarter earnings fell as it bumped up pay, repeating a pattern experienced by some of the country’s other big banks.
headline: Profit fell 13 percent for Goldman Sachs in 4th quarter as it raised employee pay.

abstract: It was the company’s second consecutive quarterly decline, the first time that had happened in over a decade.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, has staked his company’s future on an immersive online world known as the metaverse. On Wednesday, the company showed it was still navigating that transformation.
headline: Meta, Facebook’s parent, reports a 21 percent drop in profits.

abstract: Google’s parent company topped revenue and profit estimates and said that it would offer a stock dividend for the first time.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Alphabet, Google’s parent company, reported strong revenue growth in its latest quarter from its search engine and video platform, YouTube, as its market-leading position in online advertising continued to reap rewards despite recent fluctuations in the industry.
headline: Alphabet’s Revenue Jumps 15% to $80.5 Billion

abstract: The retailer pointed to “unexpectedly high costs” as a hit on its bottom line.
lead_paragraph: Target’s shares dropped nearly 25 percent on Wednesday after it reported quarterly profits that fell far short of analysts’ expectations, hit by inflation, supply issues and changing consumer habits.
headline: Target’s shares plunge after inflation takes a big bite out of profits.

abstract: Some of the biggest packaged food companies raised their prices last quarter and their profits rose, but some customers were starting to cut back or trade down.
lead_paragraph: Brenetta Smith used to buy brand-name foods like Oreos and Doritos without thinking twice. But when she noticed that food prices at her local supermarket, Aldi, were soaring, she realized she had to do something different: “I have to change the way I shop,” she said.
headline: Higher Food Prices Bring Bigger Profits, but Consumers Start to Resist

abstract: A rush to stock up on emergency contraception could mean huge profits for the investors behind the well-known morning-after pill.
lead_paragraph: Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, many women have been rushing to stock up on emergency contraception pills, in hopes of exerting more control over their bodies, or because they’re worried that the products could be restricted. (Birth control remains legal across the United States.) Drugstores have found themselves in short supply of the pills, and some are limiting purchases.
headline: Who’s Profiting From Demand for Plan B?

abstract: Both Wall Street banks, the first to report earnings this quarter, beat analysts’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: The big banks are booking big profits as customers shake off the pandemic and dealmakers seize on busy markets.
headline: JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs start earnings season strong.

abstract: Exxon, Chevron and Shell reported robust earnings and large payouts to investors as they continued to expand their fossil-fuel production.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the largest U.S. energy companies, on Friday reported sizable profits for the final quarter of last year, showing that the oil and gas industry remained robust at a time of doubts because of climate change concerns.
headline: Oil Giants Pump Their Way to Bumper Profits

abstract: The soft drink giant’s latest quarterly earnings defied worries about consumer cutbacks amid rising inflation and fragile economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola generated better-than-expected earnings as consumers continued to pay higher prices for soft drinks and juices, further evidence that shoppers are willing to keep spending in the face of record inflation and rising interest rates.
headline: Coca-Cola Keeps Raising Prices, Driving Profits Higher

abstract: Three of the biggest banks in the United States made a cumulative $22.3 billion in profit last quarter, a hefty jump from the same period last year.
lead_paragraph: Three of the biggest banks in the United States made a cumulative $22.3 billion in profit last quarter, a hefty jump from the same period last year, the lenders reported Friday.
headline: Three Big Banks Rake In Better-Than-Expected Profits

abstract: The latest quarterly results from Microsoft and Alphabet show that their big investments in artificial intelligence are on different trajectories.
lead_paragraph: The Nasdaq composite index looks set to open in the red on Wednesday, after investors got a split-screen view of how two tech giants, Microsoft and Alphabet, were doing in efforts to profit from artificial intelligence.
headline: Long on Hype, A.I. Is No Guarantee for Profits

abstract: The last time the National Automobile Dealers Association was able to hold its annual convention in person, the mood was far different. In a word, grimmer.
lead_paragraph: The last time the National Automobile Dealers Association was able to hold its annual convention in person, the mood was far different. In a word, grimmer.
headline: After bottoming out early in the pandemic, U.S. car dealers’ profits are soaring.

abstract: Despite pleas from the Biden administration for more supply, both companies said their global production fell in the first three months of the year.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the largest U.S. oil companies, on Friday reported a second consecutive quarter of robust earnings as oil and natural gas prices continued to rise after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
headline: Exxon Mobil and Chevron report big jump in profits because of higher oil and gas prices.

abstract: Both companies are investing in renewable energy, but fossil fuels still drive their earnings.
lead_paragraph: Strong profit increases from two of Europe’s largest energy companies, Royal Dutch Shell and Total, demonstrated that what really matters for the financial performance of these companies remains the price of oil and natural gas.
headline: Profits surge at Shell and Total, reflecting higher oil and gas prices.

abstract: Target reported that inflation was taking a toll on its bottom line, a day after Walmart reported the same.
lead_paragraph: A short reprieve for investors ended abruptly on Wednesday as stocks had their worst day yet in a series of already ugly drops after shrinking profits by major retailers reignited Wall Street’s fear of high inflation.
headline: Stocks resume their rout as falling profits reignite fears of inflation.

abstract: Countries have been paying about $3 to $4 per shot for AstraZeneca’s vaccine under the company’s not-for-profit pricing model.
lead_paragraph: The drug maker AstraZeneca has been selling its coronavirus vaccine at not-for-profit prices during the pandemic, as part of a promise to rollout the vaccine at cost through the crisis.
headline: AstraZeneca says it will start profiting from its vaccine.

abstract: Saudi Arabia’s national oil company earned $161 billion last year, a nearly 50 percent jump over 2021, and said demand for oil would continue.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the national oil company for Saudi Arabia, reported on Sunday that the company last year had net income of $161.1 billion — a 47 percent increase over 2021 and a record since Aramco started offering shares on the local Tadawuhl stock exchange in 2019.
headline: Saudi Aramco Reports Record Profit as Fossil Fuels Remain ‘Essential’

abstract: The Japanese conglomerate said it would take the chip designer Arm public after an anticipated sale to Nvidia fell through.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — SoftBank announced on Tuesday that it had edged back into profitability, while also confirming that it will seek to take public one of its prize holdings, the chip designer Arm, after the collapse of a hoped-for sale to Nvidia, the Silicon Valley semiconductor manufacturer.
headline: SoftBank returns to profitability, barely, as the tech sector suffers.

abstract: Despite record profits, a number of them are worried that the company is suffering from both its size and leadership from its C.E.O., Sundar Pichai.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The seeds of a company’s downfall, it is often said in the business world, are sown when everything is going great.
headline: Google Executives See Cracks in Their Company’s Success

abstract: The country’s biggest banks will report their quarterly earnings this week, reaping the benefits of an economy that’s returning to normal.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s biggest banks are about to report windfall profits as customers increase their spending and the economy bounces back from the pandemic.
headline: Bank profits are poised to surge as the pandemic recedes.

abstract: The brokerage giant, which has been swept into the turmoil surrounding the banking sector, seemed to ease fears about its financial health in its latest earnings report.
lead_paragraph: Charles Schwab generated a profit of $1.6 billion in the first quarter of the year, it said Monday, faring better than Wall Street expected and seeming to ease recent concerns about its financial health. Schwab’s stock, which plunged after the company was swept into the banking turmoil following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank last month, rose after the report.
headline: Charles Schwab’s Deposits Shrink, but Profits Grow Faster Than Expected

abstract: Frances Haugen, a Facebook product manager who left the company in May, revealed that she had provided internal documents to journalists and others.
lead_paragraph: John Tye, the founder of Whistleblower Aid, a legal nonprofit that represents people seeking to expose potential lawbreaking, was contacted this spring through a mutual connection by a woman who claimed to have worked at Facebook.
headline: Whistle-Blower Says Facebook ‘Chooses Profits Over Safety’

abstract: The company delivered 125 commercial aircraft to airlines in the three-month period, up from 122 a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Airbus announced Thursday that it had returned to a profit in the first quarter following a 1.1 billion euro loss last year because of the coronavirus pandemic, but its top executive warned that the economic toll would continue.
headline: Airbus returns to profit but warns crisis is not over.

abstract: Companies start reporting their third-quarter earnings this week, and profits are expected to have risen substantially. But worries of future growth are growing.
lead_paragraph: The Delta variant of the coronavirus has hurt hiring and made policymakers’ lives more difficult. But investors are taking it in stride, because it appears to have had little effect on corporate profits.
headline: As earnings season begins, inflation and supply chain issues cloud the outlook.

abstract: The last time the S&P 500 had a negative real earnings yield, analysts said, was in 2000, before the tech bubble burst.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. stock market has been on a run, with the S&P 500 up n more than 3 percent this week, and nearly 25 percent for the year. Fears about the Omicron variant of the coronavirus quickly faded, with stocks regaining lost ground.
headline: Corporate profits are not keeping up with inflation, a warning sign for the market.

abstract: Federal officials are investigating the railroad’s safety practices and culture after the derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, and worker deaths.
lead_paragraph: Norfolk Southern once had so few accidents and injuries that it won the rail industry’s prestigious E.H. Harriman safety award for 23 years in a row until it was retired in 2012. But in the last decade, the company has gone from an industry leader to a laggard.
headline: Norfolk Southern’s Push for Profits Compromised Safety, Workers Say

abstract: American energy production has only inched up because executives fear that oil and gas prices won’t stay high.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil and gasoline prices are climbing. Energy company profits are surging. President Biden, who came into office promising to reduce the use of fossil fuels, has effectively joined the “drill, baby, drill” chorus. Europe would love to end its dependence on Russia.
headline: Why U.S. Oil Companies Aren’t Riding to Europe’s Rescue

abstract: The trillion-dollar social media giant’s market value soared after it reported a robust profits driven by digital advertising.
lead_paragraph: Meta’s stock price soared on Friday, adding hundreds of billions of dollars to the market value of the social media giant that owns Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp.
headline: Meta’s Stock Surges After Jump in Profits

abstract: Oil and gas companies say charging them a 25 percent tax on profits could deter future investment at a critical time for Britain.
lead_paragraph: With Britain engulfed in a political crisis and Boris Johnson’s administration winding down, oil industry executives are urging the government to make changes to a windfall tax measure aimed at curbing the ballooning profits of oil and gas companies.
headline: Oil companies oppose a windfall tax in Britain despite record profits.

abstract: Some poorer countries are paying more and waiting longer for the company’s vaccine than the wealthy — if they have access at all.
lead_paragraph: Moderna, whose coronavirus vaccine appears to be the world’s best defense against Covid-19, has been supplying its shots almost exclusively to wealthy nations, keeping poorer countries waiting and earning billions in profit.
headline: Moderna, Racing for Profits, Keeps Covid Vaccine Out of Reach of Poor

abstract: The high volume of orders during the pandemic has let Amazon operate more efficiently.
lead_paragraph: With the pandemic shifting sales online and consumers flush with stimulus checks, Amazon on Thursday reported $108.5 billion in sales in the first three months of the year, up 44 percent from a year earlier. It also posted $8.1 billion in profit, an increase of 220 percent from the same period last year.
headline: Amazon’s profit soars 220 percent as pandemic drives shopping online.

abstract: The company blamed the decline on pandemic lockdowns and an increase in research and development to counter restrictions on access to U.S. technology.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei Technologies reported a nearly 70 percent plunge in annual profit on Friday, a setback that encapsulated the economic scars brought on by escalating U.S. sanctions, higher commodity prices and lingering pandemic restrictions.
headline: Huawei, Pummeled by U.S. Sanctions, Reports Plunge in Profit

abstract: Advertising revenue, which continues to be the bulk of Facebook’s income, rose 56 percent to $28.6 billion, easily surpassing Wall Street expectations.
lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Wednesday that revenue rose 56 percent to $29 billion in the three months ending in June compared with the same period last year, while profits rose 101 percent to to $10.4 billion, as the social network continues to benefit from a surge of users spending more time online during the pandemic.
headline: Facebook’s profit surges 101 percent on strong ad sales.

abstract: The toymaker was able to raise prices to offset higher costs, but its revenue took a hit overseas because of a strong dollar.
lead_paragraph: Despite higher prices, people continued to spend on Nerf blasters, Power Rangers action figures and Magic the Gathering cards, helping Hasbro overcome rising costs for materials and freight, the company said on Tuesday.
headline: Hasbro reports rising sales on strong demand, despite higher prices.

abstract: The automaker made more money on trucks and sport utility vehicles but reported bigger losses on electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor earned $1.9 billion from April to June, up from $667 million a year earlier, the company said on Thursday. Robust sales of gasoline-powered trucks and sport-utility vehicles more than offset a substantial loss on electric models.
headline: Ford’s Profit Jumped in Second Quarter

abstract: A tax benefit boosted quarterly earnings, but that masked a decline in earnings from carmaking caused by intensifying competition.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s profit from sales of electric cars slumped in the last three months of last year because of price cuts intended to thwart increasingly intense competition, the company said on Wednesday as it warned of a tough year ahead.
headline: Tesla Profit From Car Sales Falls as Price Cuts Hurt

abstract: The company indicated the reduced growth and tight margins would continue in the first three months of this year.
lead_paragraph: Amazon on Thursday reported almost no profit in the latest quarter, with unexpected weakness in its big cloud computing businesses helping to slow overall sales growth to one of its lowest levels in decades.
headline: Amazon Reports Almost No Profit and Slowing Growth

abstract: The new economic stimulus package makes a tiny change that military veterans pushed for in hopes of stemming aggressive recruiting tactics.
lead_paragraph: Military veterans have long been prized recruits at for-profit schools. The $1.9 trillion stimulus bill signed by President Biden on Thursday may change that.
headline: Congress Closes Loophole That Made Veterans a Target of For-Profit Schools

abstract: Businesses face headwinds as demand weakens, the Federal Reserve raises rates and government stimulus programs end.
lead_paragraph: The profits engine that drove stocks to their highs, making many Americans feel richer than they had in a generation, may now be working in reverse.
headline: After a Bumper 2021, Companies Might Struggle to Increase Profits

abstract: The earnings by the parent company of Google were above analysts’ estimates.
lead_paragraph: These days, there is so much uncertainty surrounding Google’s parent company, Alphabet: a global pandemic, fears of inflation gripping the U.S. economy, restive employees challenging management, and regulators and politicians seemingly bent on taking their pound of flesh.
headline: Alphabet’s profit increased 36 percent, to $20.64 billion, in the fourth quarter.
Catch up: Amazon’s profit grows 220 percent as pandemic benefits Big Tech.

abstract: The country’s trade with Russia this year has exceeded $200 billion, and makers of cars and trucks are the big winners.
lead_paragraph: On China’s snowy border with Russia, a dealership that sells trucks has seen its sales double in the past year thanks to Russian customers. China’s exports to its neighbor are so strong that Chinese construction workers built warehouses and 20-story office towers at the border this summer.
headline: War in Ukraine Has China Cashing In

abstract: The giant oil producer will spend as much as $50 billion this year on capital investments, including shale drilling.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, says it plans to use its enormous profits from last year to double down on boosting oil output capacity and move into shale drilling, which has transformed the oil industry in the United States.
headline: Saudi Aramco will use big jump in profits to invest in more oil production.

abstract: The energy giant is thriving because of soaring oil and gas prices and a tight market for refined products.
lead_paragraph: Shell reported record earnings for the second consecutive quarter on Thursday, as the energy giant continues to prosper from high oil and gas prices spurred by the war in Ukraine and other factors.
headline: Shell reports record profit, again, with $11.5 billion in latest quarter.

abstract: It was another quarter of banner financial results for the largest lender in America.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, the largest lender in the United States, made $14.5 billion in profit last quarter, a big jump from the same period last year, it reported on Friday. The bank was helped by growth virtually across the board, including increases in lending and credit-card transactions, as well as relative stability in investment banking. JPMorgan’s stock rose 0.6 percent at the close of trading.
headline: JPMorgan’s Profit Jumps, but Interest Rates Remain a Threat

abstract: Facebook’s business rose even as it dealt with controversies around the proliferation of misinformation across its platform and as it has come under increased scrutiny by regulators.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Wednesday reported surging profits and revenue driven by soaring ad sales, but cautioned that it might face “headwinds” in the future from regulation and technology changes.
headline: Facebook posts a 33 percent increase in revenue and a 53 percent jump in profit.

abstract: The electric carmaker is growing fast but investors are worried that sales are starting to slow because of higher prices and interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Tesla on Wednesday reported a big jump in its quarterly profit as sales of its electric cars soared in the three months that ended in September.
headline: Tesla Reports Strong Profit in Third Quarter on Soaring Sales

abstract: The electric-car maker’s performance reflected increasing sales and production around the world.
lead_paragraph: Tesla announced a solid quarterly financial performance on Monday reflecting continuing increases in sales and production around the world.
headline: Tesla Profit Hits a Quarterly Record

abstract: Quarterly profit at JPMorgan Chase was down, but it still earned a record $48.3 billion for the year. Citi’s annual profit nearly doubled, even though quarterly profit fell 26 percent.
lead_paragraph: Coming off a year of blockbuster profits, Wall Street is handing out fatter paychecks even as uncertainty creeps into the economic outlook.
headline: Pay on Wall Street will surge after a bumper year.

abstract: On his first day back in the top job, Howard Schultz made an abrupt change in policy at the company as it faces rising worker discontent.
lead_paragraph: As Starbucks faces a rising wave of employee unrest, its new chief executive is abruptly shifting how the coffee chain splits its profits between workers and shareholders.
headline: Starbucks’s new C.E.O. scraps stock buybacks to ‘invest more profit into our people.’

abstract: Bank executives are lately taking a more somber tone than the ebullience of recent quarters, when banks recorded blockbuster earnings.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has only clouded an already uncertain economic outlook, banking executives said this week as they reported sliding profits and growing concerns about the state of the recovery from the pandemic.
headline: Wall Street Profits Slump as War Weighs on Outlook

abstract: The company said it was close to restarting deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner plane and was on track to end the year with positive cash flow.
lead_paragraph: Boeing reported a drop in profit and weaker revenue than analysts had expected for the second quarter, but said on Wednesday that it was close to restarting deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner plane and was on track to end the year with more cash coming into the business than out of it.
headline: Boeing Reports Drop in Profit but Sees ‘Momentum’ for Turnaround

abstract: In the company’s first earnings report since Bob Iger returned as C.E.O., it exceeded Wall Street’s expectations. But about 7,000 jobs are expected to be cut.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Iger gave Disney’s corporate critics the equivalent of a punch in the mouth on Wednesday.
headline: Searching for Streaming Profit, Disney Cuts $5.5 Billion in Costs

abstract: Despite scant evidence that it works, the drug, Aduhelm, is predicted to generate billions of dollars in revenue, much of it from Medicare.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration’s decision on Monday to approve a new Alzheimer’s medication over the fierce objections of its scientific advisers sets into motion one of the most controversial drug introductions in years.
headline: Alzheimer’s Drug Is Bonanza for Biogen, Most Likely at Taxpayer Expense

abstract: Aiming to make a million electric vehicles a year by 2025, General Motors is investing in a Nevada lithium mine to help with battery production.
lead_paragraph: General Motors on Tuesday reported solid profits for 2022, after overcoming the computer chip shortages and softening demand that has slowed much of the auto industry last year.
headline: G.M. Posts Solid Profit as It Pushes to Take On Tesla in E.V.s

abstract: Analysts have begun trimming their profit forecasts, with pronounced downgrades for growth at energy and financial firms.
lead_paragraph: Stocks may have eked out gains so far in the new year, but they may not last. With corporate earnings season kicking off this week, Wall Street is pricing in a rough quarter ahead — including for itself, with Goldman Sachs and other banks preparing for layoffs.
headline: Wall Street Braces for a Weak Earnings Season

abstract: The company made $10 billion in profit for 2021, a 55 percent increase from 2020.
lead_paragraph: After a year of production disruptions due to a global computer chip shortage, General Motors said on Tuesday that its factories will be running at a normal clip again by the second half of the year.
headline: G.M. expects production to return to normal this year as a chip shortage eases.

abstract: Even as businesses have reopened, many people continue to do their shopping online, and much of that business continues to go Amazon’s way.
lead_paragraph: Amazon on Thursday followed a trend among the country’s biggest tech firms. The company said it made more money in the latest quarter compared with last year — a lot more money.
headline: Amazon’s quarterly profit jumps to $7.8 billion.

abstract: The bank’s earnings took a $2 billion hit, bringing its profit down to $3.5 billion in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo’s latest earnings took a $2 billion hit for costs related to its past scandals, dragging its profit down to $3.5 billion in the third quarter, 30 percent lower than the same period last year. But the bank’s revenue edged past analysts’ expectations, rising 4 percent from a year ago, to $19.5 billion.
headline: Wells Fargo’s Scandals Drag on Profit as It Braces for a ‘Slowing Economy’

abstract: Elon Musk’s electric car company is facing intensifying competition from newer Chinese automakers and established Western car companies.
lead_paragraph: Tesla reported a rise in profit for the second quarter after the company, led by Elon Musk, cut prices in response to increased competition and higher borrowing costs for car buyers.
headline: Tesla’s Profit Rose in the Second Quarter as Price Cuts Spurred Demand

abstract: Rising energy prices, along with cost cutting, helped secure the soaring result at Europe’s largest energy company.
lead_paragraph: Shell, Europe’s largest energy company, reported on Thursday its biggest-ever quarterly profit, reflecting high prices for oil and natural gas spurred by the war in Ukraine and tightness in world energy markets.
headline: Shell reports a record $9.1 billion profit.

abstract: The Wall Street bank recorded nearly $4 billion in profit, beating analyst expectations in a tough quarter for big banks.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a year makes at Goldman Sachs.
headline: A Slimmer Goldman Sachs Posts Hefty Jump in Profit

abstract: Alphabet, Exxon Mobil, UPS and others gave shareholders reasons to stay optimistic.
lead_paragraph: We are almost at the halfway point for earnings season, and jittery investors are looking to corporate financial reports for direction after inflation, geopolitics and other worries dragged down markets last month. It’s been a different story in the past few days, though, as robust earnings reports steadied nerves.
headline: Investors See Hope in Big Corporate Profits

abstract: $71 million of the clothing company’s earnings have been used since September 2022 to fund wildlife restoration, dam removal and Democratic groups.
lead_paragraph: A little more than $3 million to block a proposed mine in Alaska. Another $3 million to conserve land in Chile and Argentina. And $1 million to help elect Democrats around the country, including $200,000 to a super PAC this month.
headline: Patagonia’s Profits Are Funding Conservation — and Politics

abstract: Gilead delayed a new version of a drug, allowing it to extend the patent life of a blockbuster line of medications, internal documents show.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, Gilead Sciences decided to stop pursuing a new H.I.V. drug. The public explanation was that it wasn’t sufficiently different from an existing treatment to warrant further development.
headline: How a Drugmaker Profited by Slow-Walking a Promising H.I.V. Therapy

abstract: Politicians are placing more blame on greedy companies as prices stay high. But booming consumer demand is enabling firms to charge more.
lead_paragraph: Inflation remains rapid as the economy enters 2022, and Democrats have begun pointing to a new culprit for the high and lasting price increases: Greedy corporations.
headline: Democrats Blast Corporate Profits as Inflation Surges

abstract: The electric car company is facing intensifying competition, supply chain disruptions and concerns about the behavior of Elon Musk.
lead_paragraph: Tesla reported a respectable jump in profit for the last quarter of 2022, but slipping profit margins and slowing sales growth underlined the challenges that have weighed on the carmaker’s stock.
headline: Tesla’s Profit Jumped 12% in Fourth Quarter

abstract: Along with the higher spending, the owner of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp projected lighter-than-expected revenue, causing its stock to plummet.
lead_paragraph: Meta projected on Wednesday that revenue for the current quarter would be lower than what Wall Street anticipated and said it would spend billions of dollars more on its artificial intelligence efforts, even as it reported robust revenue and profits for the first three months of the year.
headline: Meta Says It Plans to Spend Billions More on A.I.

abstract: The media powerhouse remains a profit machine, but it faces challenges, including competition from newer outlets and a defamation suit against its parent company.
lead_paragraph: If Rupert Murdoch’s Fox News is at all worried about recent ratings declines, the company hid its concern well. Mr. Murdoch’s powerhouse television business continues to see growth in revenue and profit, reporting gains on both areas in its quarterly earnings report announced Tuesday.
headline: Fox News Reports Profit Gain, Despite Ratings Drop

abstract: Macy’s, Dollar General and Dollar Tree bucked a trend of retailers struggling to overcome inflationary pressures.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Macy’s, Dollar Tree and Dollar General jumped on Thursday after all three retailers reported profits that defied Wall Street’s expectations and cut against recent concerns about spending by American consumers.
headline: Retailers’ shares soar, pulling market higher, after solid earnings reports.

abstract: The carrier expects travel demand to remain strong, despite concerns about a recession.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines on Wednesday reported revenue of $12.1 billion in the three months that ended in June, its largest quarterly haul in at least a decade and the most it has ever earned in the second quarter of a year.
headline: United Airlines hits a revenue milestone, but costs constrain its quarterly profit.

abstract: The huge gain stems from the bank’s acquisition of its rival Credit Suisse this spring for about $3.2 billion, a steep discount that is skewing its quarterly results.
lead_paragraph: When UBS agreed to buy its archrival Credit Suisse for a little over $3 billion this spring at the Swiss government’s behest, analysts and investors said that price represented a steep discount. UBS’s latest financial results reflect just how much of a steal it was.
headline: UBS Reports Record-Breaking $29 Billion Profit

abstract: Economic and military uncertainty clouds the outlook for Exxon, Chevron and other energy companies, whose bonanza from high prices is already fading.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil made $56 billion in profit last year, its largest annual haul ever. Chevron earned $36 billion, also a company record. But after a bountiful 2022, the outlook for those companies and other big oil and gas producers is cloudy.
headline: What Exxon and Chevron Are Doing With Those Big Profits

abstract: Corporate profits have been bolstered by higher prices even as some of the costs of doing business have fallen in recent months.
lead_paragraph: The prices of oil, transportation, food ingredients and other raw materials have fallen in recent months as the shocks stemming from the pandemic and the war in Ukraine have faded. Yet many big businesses have continued raising prices at a rapid clip.
headline: Companies Push Prices Higher, Protecting Profits but Adding to Inflation

abstract: The internet company’s cost cuts also helped lift its financial performance in the most recent quarter.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, spent the past two years weathering a slump in digital advertising and cutting costs. This year, he proclaimed, would be a “year of efficiency” for his company.
headline: Meta Posts 23% Growth as Ads Rebound, With Profit More Than Doubling

abstract: The oil and gas giant said its earnings, which exceeded analysts’ expectations, were bolstered by strong energy trading.
lead_paragraph: Shell, Europe’s largest energy company, said Thursday that its profit jumped 6 percent in the first quarter to $9.6 billion, a sign that the company remains hugely profitable, even with oil prices under pressure.
headline: Shell Reports $9.6 Billion Profit, Despite Falling Oil Prices

abstract: The company said rivals were swarming the market and increasing competition and that it was spending heavily on marketing and development to keep ahead of its competitors.
lead_paragraph: The cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase said on Thursday that its quarterly profit soared by more than 20 times from a year earlier as its revenue skyrocketed, in a sign of how enthusiasm for digital currencies has gone mainstream in the pandemic.
headline: Coinbase made $771 million in profit in the first quarter, benefiting from crypto mania.

abstract: Revenue was up 11 percent from a year earlier, helping to generate $221 million in net income.
lead_paragraph: Uber on Tuesday reported financial results that showed its business was continuing to steadily chug along — and even turn a profit — as more riders and drivers used its platform than ever before.
headline: Uber Reports Record Ridership and Second Straight Quarterly Profit

abstract: As profits slowed at Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase, executives said that lending to consumers and businesses remained healthy but that risks loomed “down the road.”
lead_paragraph: Slowing demand and sinking markets have put an end to a period of record-setting profits for the country’s biggest banks, but that doesn’t mean a recession is imminent, top bankers say, even if it may look like they are preparing for one.
headline: Big Banks Prepare for Downturn, but Don’t See Recession Yet

abstract: The carmaker had a profit of $5.5 billion as sales of its electric vehicles kept soaring, especially in China and Europe.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said Wednesday that its profit leapt more than sixfold last year to $5.5 billion, the highest total in its 19-year history, as sales soared further, especially in Europe and China.
headline: Tesla reports record yearly profit but warns that supply problems persist.

abstract: Earnings nearly tripled, showing that oil retains a large role in the global economy despite climate change concerns.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said Sunday that its profits for the third quarter nearly tripled compared with the period a year earlier, as demand for the fuel recovers from the pandemic and prices soar.
headline: Saudi Aramco reports a $30 billion quarterly profit as oil prices soar.

abstract: The oil giant is benefiting from high prices in energy markets.
lead_paragraph: Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, indicated Thursday that it was continuing to profit handsomely from oil market conditions that have motorists screaming.
headline: Shell sees refining profits nearly tripling, adding $1 billion to its bottom line.

abstract: Quarterly profits decreased 8 percent, to $10.3 billion, from a year earlier. Shares of Meta’s stock plunged about 22 percent in after-hours trading.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg said his company was going all in on the metaverse last year. On Wednesday, he showed the costs of making that transition.
headline: Meta spent $10 billion on the metaverse in 2021, dragging down profit.

abstract: The energy industry’s windfall followed a spike in prices, resulting mostly from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the global economic rebound from the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest energy companies in the United States, said on Friday that profits rose to record levels in the second quarter as they continued to reap the benefits of soaring oil and gas prices.
headline: Exxon and Chevron Report Record Profits on High Oil and Gas Prices

abstract: After a disappointing quarter, the Finnish technology company announced significant spending cuts.
lead_paragraph: Nokia announced a major overhaul of its business on Thursday that includes slashing up to 14,000 jobs, or about 16 percent of its work force, over the next three years.
headline: Nokia to Cut 14,000 Jobs in Major Overhaul at Telecom Giant

abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and Citigroup said that consumers continued to borrow and spend, but their chiefs warned that geopolitical risks were intensifying.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, is as close as Wall Street has to a statesman, and on Friday he sounded a major alarm about the global effects of the conflict in Israel and Gaza.
headline: Dimon Warns of ‘Most Dangerous Time’ as Banks Report Big Profits

abstract: Delta said its March operations were profitable, despite rising fuel costs. It reported a first-quarter loss, but revenue exceeded its forecast.
lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines reported a quarterly loss on Wednesday as thriving ticket sales were offset by high fuel prices. But it said that its March operations were profitable and that it had been able to pass some of the higher cost of fuel along to customers.
headline: Delta Air Lines sees a turn toward profit, and carriers’ shares soar.

abstract: Daimler, the German car and truck maker, said Thursday that its net profit rose by nearly 50 percent in 2020, as it managed to cut costs more than enough to compensate for a decline in sales and supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Daimler, the German car and truck maker, said Thursday that its net profit rose by nearly 50 percent in 2020, as it managed to cut costs more than enough to compensate for a decline in sales and supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic.
headline: Defying the pandemic, Daimler reports a big jump in profit.

abstract: Investors are pouring money into the less exclusive cousin of tennis.
lead_paragraph: As pickleball takes over the minds and courts of America, investors are pouncing on the opportunity to turn a favorite casual pickup game into a massive professional sport.
headline: Pickleball Went Pro. Can It Profit?

abstract: The Silicon Valley company was again lifted by sales of its artificial intelligence chips, but it faces growing competition and heightened expectations.
lead_paragraph: Nvidia, which makes microchips that power most artificial intelligence applications, began an extraordinary run a year ago.
headline: Nvidia, Powered by A.I. Boom, Reports Soaring Revenue and Profits

abstract: Delta’s quarterly profit, which was buoyed by $1.5 billion in federal stimulus money, was still down 55 percent from the same quarter in 2019.
lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines on Wednesday reported a $652 million profit in the second quarter of the year, its first since the pandemic began and the latest sign that the airline recovery is well underway. The carrier reported $7.1 billion in revenue.
headline: Delta Air Lines reports its first profit since the start of the pandemic.

abstract: Nearly 3.5 billion people now use one of Facebook’s apps every month.
lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Wednesday that revenue rose 48 percent to $26.2 billion in the first three months of the year, while profits nearly doubled to $9.5 billion, underlining how the social network has continued to benefit during the pandemic.
headline: Facebook nearly doubles its profit and revenue rises 48 percent, as tech booms.

abstract: The company, which announced plans to lay off 10,000 workers last week, had warned that was facing a significant slowdown in the growth of its sales.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Tuesday reported its slowest growth in six years and cautioned that a broader slump will continue as both consumers and businesses put the brakes on spending.
headline: Microsoft Revenue Up 2 Percent, but Profit Drops 12 Percent

abstract: Both airlines said they expected to do even better in the final three months of the year, lifted by corporate, international and holiday travel.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines and Southwest Airlines reported profits for the three months ended in September, reflecting the industry’s recovery despite the spread of the Delta variant of the coronavirus. But the airlines aren’t entirely out of the woods: Both would have reported losses were it not for federal pandemic aid.
headline: American and Southwest post profits as the airline industry recovers.

abstract: Nearly 30 percent of Instacart’s revenue came from advertising, and grocery orders were flat in the first half of this year, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Instacart, the grocery delivery business that boomed during the pandemic, took a step on Friday toward an initial public offering that will be a test of Wall Street’s appetite for tech start-ups after a yearlong industry slump.
headline: Instacart Reveals $428 Million in Profit but Slowing Growth Ahead of I.P.O.

abstract: The move shows how inflation and changing consumer behavior are souring the business outlook for many retailers.
lead_paragraph: Target plans to cut prices and cancel orders to clear out unwanted inventory, announcing a series of steps on Tuesday to combat inflation and supply chain disruptions. The actions would cut its profit in the current quarter, the company said, pushing its shares down. Target’s share price closed down 2.4 percent.
headline: Target will take a profit hit to clear out inventory that shoppers don’t want.

abstract: Revenue fell 5 percent from a year earlier, but the automaker said chip availability had “markedly improved” since the previous quarter.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor reported $1.8 billion in profit for the three months that ended in September, a decline of $600 million from a year earlier that the company attributed mainly to the global shortage of computer chips.
headline: Ford’s profit declines as automakers deal with supply-chain troubles.

abstract: The two European companies reported earnings totaling nearly $20 billion, partly on higher energy prices as Russia’s war in Ukraine continues.
lead_paragraph: Gargantuan profits continue to roll in at Europe’s energy giants. London-based Shell reported adjusted earnings of $9.45 billion for the third quarter, its second-highest profit on record. On the same day, Paris-based TotalEnergies reported a profit of $9.9 billion.
headline: Shell and Total, Oil Giants, Report Huge Profits on High Energy Prices

abstract: Google’s parent company reported its fourth consecutive drop in quarterly profit, weeks after culling 6 percent of its work force to cut costs.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, has settled into a period of stalled growth as economic uncertainty reverberates across Silicon Valley. Gone are the pandemic boom times, when the internet giant’s profit and employee head count soared.
headline: Alphabet’s Profit Falls 34% Amid Ads Slowdown

abstract: The drop meant that for the first time in years, Walmart did not meet Wall Street’s profit expectations, an ominous signal for other companies navigating inflation.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, the nation’s largest retailer, is being hit hard by inflation. The company reported on Tuesday that its profit in the first three months of the year fell 25 percent from a year ago, an unexpectedly large drop that Walmart blamed on broadly higher costs, particularly in labor and fuel.
headline: Walmart profits drop, dragged down by higher costs for food and fuel.

abstract: The maker of Gatorade and Lay’s, which nearly doubled its profit in its latest quarter, has been raising prices by double-digit percentages for more than a year.
lead_paragraph: PepsiCo reported a big jump in quarterly profit on Thursday, despite signs that customers are buying fewer cans of soda and bags of chips as the company continues to raise prices aggressively.
headline: Price Increases Lead to Big Jump in Profit at PepsiCo

abstract: Safety experts say a focus on financial returns may be partly to blame for derailments and accidents like the one in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Last month, as Norfolk Southern, one of the largest railroads in North America, reported record operating profits, Alan H. Shaw, its chief executive, told shareholders that the company’s service was “at the best it’s been in more than two years.”
headline: Norfolk Southern’s Profits and Accident Rates Rose in Recent Years

abstract: Bumper earnings from Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, and BP were, nonetheless, a slight decline from the previous quarter.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said on Tuesday that it had earned $42.4 billion in net income in the third quarter. The figure was more than double the nearly $20 billion that Exxon Mobil earned for the period.
headline: Saudi Aramco Reports $42 Billion in Profit as Cash Rolls In for Oil Giants

abstract: The London-based energy giant said it had benefited from reviving demand for oil and OPEC’s management of output.
lead_paragraph: BP said Tuesday that higher oil and natural gas prices had led to sharply higher earnings in the third quarter. The company said that its “underlying replacement cost profit” for July through September was $3.3 billion, compared with $86 million in the period a year earlier.
headline: BP’s profit rises as oil and gas prices soar.

abstract: Stock markets in Mumbai have surged as big global investors hope India can become a source of growth. It won’t be so easy.
lead_paragraph: Mumbai, India’s financial capital, has seen a lot of new faces over the past year. The heads of global banks have been trooping through, visiting its stock exchanges, buying property and hiring new staff.
headline: Wall Street Lands on India, Looking for Profits It Can’t Find in China

abstract: Profit and sales at the tech giant, the first of the largest tech companies to report earnings for the three months ending in December, grew about 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft announced record profit and sales on Tuesday despite investor fears that the pandemic-fueled tech boom may be over.
headline: Microsoft’s profit continues to climb.

abstract: Citing the need to cut prices to move inventory, the company slashed its earnings outlook for the year, sending its stock price tumbling in after-hours trading.
lead_paragraph: Walmart lowered its profit outlook on Monday, saying inflation is pressuring its customers to make fewer purchases of general merchandise and to focus on necessities like groceries.
headline: Walmart lowers profit forecast as inflation hits customers’ wallets.

abstract: The iPhone maker said it was hurt by Covid-related shutdowns of factories in Shanghai but benefited from its growing services business.
lead_paragraph: For years, Apple has surged behind large-scale manufacturing and rising sales in China. But, lately, the tech giant’s reliance on the world’s most populous country has veered from a strength to a vulnerability.
headline: Apple Continues to Grow, but Profits Drop as Costs Rise

abstract: Ford has had to halt or slow production of highly profitable models like the F-150 pickup truck and various sport-utility vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said on Wednesday that its profit for the three months that ended in June fell by about 50 percent, to $561 million, in large part because a global shortage of computer chips kept the company from selling more cars and trucks.
headline: Ford profit drops 50 percent because of a global chip shortage.
Catch up: Google’s and Microsoft’s profits soar as pandemic benefits Big Tech.

abstract: The company also reported that profit more than tripled, to $10.4 billion, topping Wall Street expectations.
lead_paragraph: Amazon reported its highest first-quarter profit on Tuesday as it continued to wring efficiencies out of its retail business and recharge growth in its cloud computing operations.
headline: Amazon Reports $143.3 Billion in Revenue for First Quarter of 2024

abstract: The electric carmaker has reduced prices by thousands of dollars this year to bolster demand and fend off competition.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s profit fell sharply in the first three months of the year after it cut the prices of its electric vehicles, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Tesla’s Profit Dropped Sharply in First Quarter as It Cut Prices

abstract: The carrier reported a healthy profit for the third quarter after a busy summer. Competitors also seem confident despite economic turbulence.
lead_paragraph: Broad economic turmoil and sustained inflation have done little to shake Delta Air Lines’ confidence in travel demand for the rest of the year after it ended summer on a high note.
headline: Delta Earnings Are Solid as Airline Signals Optimism on Travel Demand

abstract: Sales increased from a year earlier, when the automaker was hampered by parts shortages.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor reported a solid profit in the first quarter, although the automaker indicated that its turnaround was not complete and that it had a ways to go before it starts making money on electric vehicles.
headline: Ford Reports $1.8 Billion Profit in Quarter

abstract: India, a critical security partner of the United States, now buys huge amounts of Russian oil, purchasing one of every two barrels shipped at sea.
lead_paragraph: India, a critical security partner of the United States, now buys huge amounts of Russian oil, purchasing one of every two barrels shipped at sea.
headline: How India Profits From Its Neutrality in the Ukraine War

abstract: The Federal Reserve chair spent the early pandemic bemoaning the loss of a strong job market. It roared back — and now its fate is in his hands.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, spent the early pandemic lamenting something America had lost: a job market so historically strong that it was boosting marginalized groups, extending opportunities to people and communities that had long lived without them.
headline: Jerome Powell’s Prized Labor Market Is Back. Can He Keep It?

abstract: Speaking at a news conference, Ms. Yellen said that she did not believe the U.S. was in a recession
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen on Thursday dismissed questions about whether the U.S. economy was already in a recession, pointing to the strong labor market and other metrics as signs of its health.
headline: Treasury Secretary Yellen said the U.S. economy was transitioning to ‘steady, sustainable’ growth.

abstract: United Airlines and other companies have started a $100 million fund to invest in jet fuel that produces fewer greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: A flurry of investments, policy changes and technological breakthroughs is giving a jolt of energy to the nascent market for sustainable aviation fuel, a low-carbon alternative to traditional jet fuel made from crude oil.
headline: A Sudden Rush to Make Sustainable Aviation Fuel Mainstream

abstract: Larry Fink is using his firm’s huge influence to pressure companies to eliminate greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
lead_paragraph: A year ago this month, the BlackRock chief Laurence D. Fink wrote a letter to the world’s C.E.O.s with an urgent message: Climate change will be “a defining factor in companies’ long-term prospects.” Underscoring his point, he added, “We are on the edge of a fundamental reshaping of finance.”
headline: BlackRock Chief Pushes a Big New Climate Goal for the Corporate World

abstract: Nexii Building Solutions in Vancouver is having significant early success, though there are potential pitfalls.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Upstart, a series on young companies harnessing new science and technology.
headline: Can a Start-Up Make Sustainable Construction the Next Frontier in Eco-Business?

abstract: An enduring traffic jam at the Port of Savannah reveals why the chaos in global shipping is likely to persist.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Like toy blocks hurled from the heavens, nearly 80,000 shipping containers are stacked in various configurations at the Port of Savannah — 50 percent more than usual.
headline: ‘It’s Not Sustainable’: What America’s Port Crisis Looks Like Up Close

abstract: Hemp blocks are costlier than traditional building products, but they help address environmental issues and can shave 20 to 30 percent off a typical construction schedule.
lead_paragraph: As ballroom dancers twirl, and competitive Ping-Pong players swing their paddles in the French town of Croissy-Beaubourg, they are doing so in what some describe as the future of building construction.
headline: In Search for Sustainable Materials, Developers Turn to Hemp

abstract: More cities are adopting deconstruction ordinances that require older homes to be taken down for salvageable parts, but they face challenges in trying to expand their efforts.
lead_paragraph: As the green building movement evolves beyond energy efficiency into new areas of sustainability, one promising effort focuses on finding new life for used building materials, though advocates say they are struggling with how to expand this niche market.
headline: Sustainability Advocates Ask: Why Demolish When You Can Deconstruct?

abstract: The company, which brought in about $219 million in revenue last year, posted losses for the last two years, and it expects more losses to come.
lead_paragraph: Allbirds, the maker of wool sneakers, offered a long-awaited peek at its earnings when its filing for an initial public offering was made public on Tuesday, revealing strong digital sales in 2020 despite an annual loss.
headline: Allbirds’s I.P.O. filing shows losses but grand ambitions for its sustainable shoes.

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has stepped up scrutiny of sustainable investing, which has become popular but is said to lack accountability.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Goldman Sachs over its E.S.G. investment funds — funds that invest in companies that say they are committed to environmental, social and governance principles, according to two people familiar with the matter.
headline: Goldman Sachs Is Being Investigated Over E.S.G. Funds

abstract: Developers are no longer aiming to simply preserve nature, but are actively restoring it as a selling point for their projects.
lead_paragraph: When the online travel giant Expedia Group unveiled its $900 million Seattle headquarters in 2019, the 40-acre waterfront campus showcased numerous amenities: a bike path, a soccer field and a beach strewn with driftwood logs for sitting amid the sounds of surf.
headline: The Next Level in Sustainability: Nature Restoration

abstract: The effort to steer public and private money toward nuclear power stations and gas-fired generators in the European Union was criticized as greenwashing.
lead_paragraph: The European Union said on Wednesday that it would label some nuclear power and natural gas plants, under certain conditions, as “transitional” green investments in order to drastically cut the continent’s greenhouse gas emissions.
headline: Europe labels nuclear and natural gas as sustainable investments.

abstract: A new report showed that $13 billion was withdrawn last year from funds that invest in companies with environmental, social and governance principles.
lead_paragraph: The money flowing out of funds that invest in companies with environmental, social and governance principles has gone from a trickle to a torrent as investors sour on a sector hit by green-washing concerns, red-state boycotts and boardroom debates.
headline: Investors Pull Billions From Sustainable Funds Amid Political Heat

abstract: S&P cited racial discrimination claims in deciding to exclude the electric carmaker from a listing of socially responsible companies.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk called a prominent index of socially responsible companies a “scam” on Wednesday after it dropped Tesla because of the way the carmaker handled accusations of racial discrimination at its factory in California.
headline: Sustainability Index Drops Tesla, Prompting Insult from Musk

abstract: Vehicle makers shy away from traditional materials that are hard to recycle, like leather and plastics, and look to repurpose alternatives that still convey quality.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, Chrysler’s TV commercials played up its vehicles’ “rich Corinthian leather.” That meaningless phrase, dreamed up by marketers and cooed by the actor Ricardo Montalbán, became emblematic of what defined a luxury vehicle.
headline: Building a More Sustainable Car, From Headlamp to Tailpipe

abstract: The organizer of New York Fashion Week has pledged to achieve a net-zero goal by 2050, but agreements among fashion houses risk violating competition rules.
lead_paragraph: It’s New York Fashion Week, a biannual celebration of luxury and consumption when designers show their collections and set the trends for the season ahead. Also in the spotlight will be questions about the industry’s environmental destructiveness.
headline: How ‘sustainable fashion’ could run afoul of antitrust regulators.
